name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the northeastern United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by the state of New York, to the east, to the southeast and south by the Atlantic Ocean, to the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania, and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 inhabitants in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 American states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, while the largest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of the counties in New Jersey are located in the combined New York City or Philadelphia statistical areas; therefore, the largest metropolitan area of the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was inhabited for the first time by Amerindians for at least 2,800 years, with Lenape as the dominant group when Europeans arrived in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European colonies in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The English later seized control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey, after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey, and granted it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, first Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several major battles during the American Revolutionary War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, the factories of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the country's industrial revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeastern megalopolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the twenty-first century, the state's economy became increasingly diverse, while its multicultural population began to return to more urban areas within the state, thus exceeding the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: By 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all US states, with 9.76% of households — more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million in the state as a whole — meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, it was the second poorest U.S. state by median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public school system is consistently ranked among the 50 or best states in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey bordered North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the collision between North America and Africa gave rise to the Appalachians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, the ice age led to glaciers that reached New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as many rivers, marshes and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Originally, New Jersey was established by the Amerindians, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is the name of Lenape for the land which is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in corn farming to complete their hunting and harvesting in the area surrounding the Delaware River, the lower Hudson River and the western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Lenape was divided into matrilineal clans based on common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: Turtle, Turkey and Wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first met the Dutch at the beginning of the 17th century, and their main relationship with Europeans was the fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first Europeans to claim land in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherlands consisted of parts of modern states of the Middle Atlantic.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the European principle of land ownership was not recognized by the Lenape, Dutch West India Company policy required its settlers to purchase the land they settled.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first to do so was Michiel Pauw, who in 1630 established a patron saint named Pavonia along the North River, which eventually became Bergen.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Peter Minuit's purchase of land along the Delaware River established the colony of New Sweden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The entire region became a territory of England on 24 June 1664, after an English fleet under Colonel Richard Nicolls sailed in what is now New York Harbor and took control of Fort Amsterdam, annexing the entire province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the English Civil War, Channel Island of Jersey remained loyal to the British Crown and gave refuge to the king.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Charles II of England was proclaimed king in 1649, after the execution of his father, Charles I, from the royal square of Saint-Hélier.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The North American lands were divided by Charles II, who gave his brother, the Duke of York (later King James II), the area between New England and Maryland as an exclusive colony (as opposed to a royal colony).

name: new_jersey
sentence: James then granted the land between the Hudson River and the Delaware River (the land that would become New Jersey) to two friends who had remained faithful during the English Civil War: Sir George Carteret and Lord Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The area was called the Province of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since the creation of the state, New Jersey has been characterized by ethnic and religious diversity.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Congregationalists from New England settle alongside Scottish Presbyterians and Dutch Reformed Migrants.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the majority of residents lived in cities with 100-acre (40 ha) individual lands, some wealthy landowners owned large properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: English Quakers and Anglicans owned large land properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike the Plymouth, Jamestown, and other colonies, New Jersey was populated by a second wave of immigrants from other colonies instead of those who migrated directly from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey remained agrarian and rural throughout the colonial era, and commercial agriculture grew sporadically.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some townships, such as Burlington on the Delaware River and Perth Amboy, have emerged as important ports for shipping to New York and Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The colony's fertile land and tolerant religious policy attracted more settlers, and the population of New Jersey increased to 120,000 in 1775.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the first 10 years of English domination, settlement took place along the Hackensack River and Arthur Kill-settlers came mainly from New York and New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 18 March 1673 Berkeley sold his half of the colony to Quakers, England, which established the Delaware Valley region as a Quaker colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: (William Penn acted for some time as trustee for the land.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was governed very briefly as two distinct provinces, east and west of Jersey, for 28 years, between 1674 and 1702, sometimes part of the province of New York or the Dominion of New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1702 the two provinces were reunited under a royal governor, rather than an exclusive province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Edward Hyde, Lord Cornbury, became the first governor of the colony as a royal colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Britain believed that he was an ineffective and corrupt ruler, taking bribes and speculating on the earth.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1708 he was recalled to England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was then governed by the governors of New York, but that irritated the settlers of New Jersey, who accused these governors of favouritism in New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Justice Lewis Morris led the case for a separate governor, and was appointed governor by King George II in 1738.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was one of the Thirteen Colonies that rebelled against British domination in the American Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Constitution of New Jersey of 1776 was adopted on 2 July 1776, just two days before the Second Continental Congress declared Britain's American independence.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is an act of the Provincial Congress, which has become a state legislature.

name: new_jersey
sentence: To reassure the neutrals, she predicted that it would become null if New Jersey were to achieve reconciliation with Britain.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Representatives of New Jersey Richard Stockton, John Witherspoon, Francis Hopkinson, John Hart and Abraham Clark were among those who signed the United States Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, British and American armies crossed New Jersey many times, and several crucial battles took place in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As a result, New Jersey today is often called "The Crossroad of the American Revolution".

name: new_jersey
sentence: The winter quarters of the Continental Army were established twice by General George Washington in Morristown, which was called "The Military Capital of the American Revolution".

name: new_jersey
sentence: On the night of December 25-26, 1776, the continental army under George Washington crossed the Delaware River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: After the crossing, he surprised and defeated the Hessian troops at the Battle of Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A little more than a week after the victory in Trenton, the American forces won a major victory by stopping General Cornwallis' charges at the second Battle of Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: By escaping Cornwallis' army, Washington made a surprise attack on Princeton and successfully defeated British forces there on 3 Jan. 1777.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The painting by Emanuel Leutze of Washington Crossing the Delaware became an icon of the Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The American forces under Washington met forces under General Henry Clinton during the Battle of Monmouth during an undecided engagement in June 1778.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Washington tried to take the British column by surprise; when the British army tried to flank the Americans, the Americans withdrew into disorder.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The ranks were then reorganized and resisted British accusations.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the summer of 1783, the Continental Congress met at Nassau Hall, Princeton University, making Princeton the capital of the country for four months.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was there that the Continental Congress learned of the signing of the Treaty of Paris (1783), which ended the war.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 18 December 1787, New Jersey became the third state to ratify the United States Constitution, which was very popular in New Jersey because it prevented New York and Pennsylvania from imposing tariffs on goods imported from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 20 November 1789, the State became the first of the newly created Union to ratify the Charter of Rights.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Jersey of 1776 gave the vote to "all the inhabitants" who had a certain level of wealth.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This includes women and blacks, but not married women, because they cannot own property separated from their husbands.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Both parties, in several elections, claimed that the other party had voted unqualified and mocked them for using "jump voters", whether or not they had the right to vote; on the other hand, both parties had passed laws on voting rights.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1807, the legislator passed a bill interpreting the constitution as meaning the universal suffrage of white men, to the exclusion of the poor; the constitution itself was a law of the legislator and was not included as the modern constitution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 15 February 1804, New Jersey became the last northern state to abolish slavery and enacted legislation that slowly eliminated existing slavery.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This has led to a gradual decline in the slave population.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the end of the civil war, a dozen African Americans from New Jersey were still in bondage.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey voters initially refused to ratify the constitutional amendments prohibiting slavery and granting rights to the black population of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Industrialization accelerated in the northern part of the state after the completion of the Morris Canal in 1831.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The canal brought coal from the eastern Lehigh Valley to the growing industries of northern New Jersey in Paterson, Newark and Jersey City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1844, the second constitution of the State was ratified and brought into force.

sentence: The counties thus became districts for the state senate, and a certain realignment of borders (including the creation of Mercer County) immediately followed.

sentence: This provision was retained in the 1947 Constitution, but was overturned by the United States Supreme Court in 1962 by Baker v. Carr.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the government was stronger than in the constitution of 1776, the constitution of 1844 created many offices that were not responsible to him or to the people, and he gave him a three-year term, but he could not succeed himself.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was one of the few states in the Union (the others being Delaware and Kentucky) to choose a candidate other than Abraham Lincoln twice in the national election, and he joined Stephen Douglas (1860) and George B. McClellan (1864) in their campaigns.

name: new_jersey
sentence: McClellan, from Philadelphia, had ties to New Jersey and was officially resident in New Jersey at the time; he later became governor of New Jersey (1878–81).

sentence: During the American civil war, the state was led first by Republican Governor Charles Smith Olden and then by Democrat Joel Parker.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the course of the war, more than 80,000 members of the state enlisted in the northern army; unlike many states, some of them from the north, no battle was fought there.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the industrial revolution, cities like Paterson grew and flourished.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Previously, the economy had been largely agrarian, which was problematic due to the failure of crops and poor soil quality.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This has led to a shift to a more industrialized economy based on manufactured products such as textiles and silk.

sentence: The southern, central and northeastern parts of the state have a humid subtropical climate, while the northwest has a humid (microthermal) continental climate, with much colder temperatures due to higher elevations.

sentence: New Jersey receives between 2,400 and 2,800 hours of sunshine per year.

sentence: Climate change is affecting New Jersey faster than most other United States.

sentence: Since 1895 average temperatures have risen by nearly 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, twice the average of the other lower 48 states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid, with mean temperatures at 82–87°F (28–31°C) and 60–69°F (16–21°C); however, temperatures above 90°F (32°C) on average 25 days each summer, exceeding 100°F (38°C) in some years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Winters are generally cold, with mean high temperatures of 34–43°F (1–6°C) and lows of 16–28°F (−9–2°C) for most of the state, but temperatures may fall for short periods below 10°F (−12°C) and sometimes above 50°F (10°C).

name: new_jersey
sentence: The northwestern parts of the state have significantly colder winters, with the sub-0°F (−18°C) being an almost annual occurrence.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Spring and fall may have large temperature variations, with less humidity than summer.

sentence: The USDA Hardiness Zone classification ranges from 6 in the northwest of the state to 7B near Cape May.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Extreme temperatures recorded in New Jersey include 110°F (43°C) on July 10, 1936, at Runyon, Middlesex County, and −34°F (−37°C) on January 5, 1904, at River Vale, Bergen County.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Average annual precipitation ranges from 43 to 51 inches (1100 to 1,300 mm), evenly distributed throughout the year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Average snowfalls per winter season range from 10 to 15 inches (25 to 38 cm) in the south and near the coast, from 15 to 30 inches (38 to 76 cm) in the northeast and central states, to about 40 to 50 inches (1.0 to 1.3 m) in the northwest highlands, but this often varies considerably from year to year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Precipitation falls on average 120 days a year, with 25 to 30 thunderstorms, most of which occur during the summer.

sentence: New Jersey is divided into 21 counties

sentence: New Jersey was completely divided into counties in 1692.

sentence: New Jersey is the only state in the nation where elected county officials are called "Freeholders", which governs each county on its own board of directors of the elected Freeholders.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The number of free owners in each county is determined by referendum and must be composed of three, five, seven or nine members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Depending on the county, executive and legislative functions may be exercised by the board of directors of the free owners elected or divided into different branches of government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 16 counties, members of the board of directors of voting rights holders perform legislative and executive functions on a commission basis, each voting right holder being responsible for a department or group of departments.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the other five counties (Atlantic, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Mercer), there is a directly elected county executive who performs executive functions while the board of directors of the voting rights holders retains a legislative and supervisory role.

sentence: In counties without executive management, a county administrator (or county director) may be hired to provide day-to-day administration of county functions.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey currently has 565 municipalities; the number was 566 prior to the merger of Princeton Township and Princeton Borough to form the Municipality of Princeton on January 1, 2013.

sentence: Unlike other states, all land in New Jersey is part of a municipality.

sentence: In 2008, Governor Jon Corzine proposed to reduce state aid to all cities with less than 10 000 inhabitants, in order to encourage mergers to reduce administrative costs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since the twentieth century, largely driven by reform objectives, a series of six modern forms of government have been implemented.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Walsh Act, enacted in 1911 by the Legislative Assembly of New Jersey, provided for a three or five-member non-partisanly elected commission.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The 1923 Municipal Director Act, which provided for a non-partisan council, provided for a weak mayor elected by and from the council, and introduced a government structure to manage municipal affairs with a manager appointed for day-to-day administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Faulkner Act, which was enacted in 1950 and largely amended in 1981, provides for four basic plans: the mayor-counsel, the council-manager, the small municipality and the mayor-counsel-administrative.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Act offers many choices to communities that prefer strong executive and professional management of municipal affairs and provides great flexibility to allow municipalities to choose the characteristics of their government: the number of seats on the council; the seats chosen in general, by electoral districts or by a combination of the two; staggered or concurrent terms; and a mayor chosen by the council or directly elected by the electors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most major municipalities and the majority of New Jersey residents are governed by municipalities with Faulkner Charters Act.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Municipalities may also formulate their own form of government and operate under a Special Charter with the approval of the Legislative Assembly of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although municipalities retain their names derived from types of government, they may have changed for one of the modern forms of government, or even more so in the past for one of the other traditional forms, leading to municipalities whose formal names are rather dishonest for the general public.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, although there are four municipalities that are officially village-type, Loch Arbour is the only one remaining with the form of village government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The other three villages (Ridgefield Park (now a Walsh Act), Ridgewood (now a Faulkner Act Council-Manager) and South Orange (now a Special Charter) all migrated to other non-village forms.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern part of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: It was one of the thirteen colonies of origin, forming the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: With a total area of 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2), New York is the 27th largest state.

name: new_york
sentence: Its population of over 19 million in 2019 makes it the fourth most populous.

name: new_york
sentence: Sometimes called New York State, it is the home of New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Two thirds of the state's population live in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: With an estimated population of 8.34 million in 2019, New York is the most populous city in the United States and the first gateway to immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The metropolitan area of New York is one of the most populated in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: As a world city, New York City is home to the United Nations Headquarters and has been described as the world's cultural, financial and media capital, as well as the world's most economically powerful city.

name: new_york
sentence: The four most populous cities in the state are Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, while Albany is the capital of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a diverse geography.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the south and Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont to the east.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a maritime border with Rhode Island, east of Long Island, and an international border with the Canadian provinces of Quebec to the north and Ontario to the northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern portion of the state is located on the Atlantic coastal plain and includes Long Island and several smaller associated islands, as well as the City of New York and the lower Hudson River valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The large area of Upstate New York includes several ranges of larger Appalachian mountains, and Adirondack Mountains in the northeast lobe of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The north-south valley of the Hudson River and the east-west valley of the Mohawk River are bisects of these more mountainous regions.

name: new_york
sentence: The western part of New York is considered to be part of the Great Lakes region and its boundaries are Lake Ontario, Lake Erie and Niagara Falls.

name: new_york
sentence: The central part of the state is dominated by Finger Lakes, a popular tourist destination and holiday.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and Iroquoian Indians for several hundred years as the first Europeans arrived in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: French settlers and Jesuit missionaries arrived south of Montreal to trade and proselytize.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1609 the area was visited by Henry Hudson, who sailed for the Dutch East India Company.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch built Fort Nassau in 1614 at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk rivers, where the present capital of Albany developed later.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch soon established New Amsterdam and parts of the Hudson Valley, establishing the multicultural colony of New Earth, a trade and immigration centre.

name: new_york
sentence: England seized the colony of the Dutch in 1664.

name: new_york
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), a group of settlers from New York Province attempted to take control of the British colony and finally succeeded in establishing independence.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, the development of the interior by New York, beginning with the Erie Canal, gave it incomparable advantages over other parts of the east coast and built its political and cultural ascendant.

name: new_york
sentence: Many landmarks in New York are well known, including four of the ten most visited tourist attractions in the world in 2013: Times Square, Central Park, Niagara Falls and Grand Central Terminal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: In the twenty-first century, New York became a global hub of creativity and entrepreneurship, social tolerance and environmental sustainability.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has about 200 colleges and universities, including the State University of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Several were ranked among the top 100 countries and countries in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The tribes of what is now New York were mainly Haudenosaunee and Algonquian.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island was divided roughly into two parts between Wampanoag and Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: Lenape also controlled most of the area surrounding the port of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: To the north of Lenape was a third Algonquian nation, the Mohicans.

name: new_york
sentence: To the north of them, from east to west, were three Iroquoian nations: the Mohawks, the original Iroquois and the Petuns.

name: new_york
sentence: To the south of them, divided about along Appalachia, were the Susquehannock and the Erie.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Wampanoag and Mohican peoples were caught in the war of King Philip, a joint effort of many New England tribes to repel Europeans from their lands.

name: new_york
sentence: After the death of their leader, Chief Philip Metacomet, most of these peoples fled inside, dividing themselves into Abenaki and Schaghticoke.

name: new_york
sentence: Many Mohicans remained in the area until the 1800s, however, a small group known as Ouabano migrated southwest to western Virginia at an earlier time.

name: new_york
sentence: Maybe they merged with the Shawnee.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks and Susquehannock were the most militaristic.

name: new_york
sentence: By trying to stem trade with Europeans, they targeted other tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks were also known for refusing white colonization on their land and for banishing any people who had converted to Christianity.

name: new_york
sentence: They posed a major threat to the Abenakis and Mohicans, while the Susquehannock briefly conquered the Lenape in the 1600s.

name: new_york
sentence: The most devastating event of the century, however, was Beaver's wars.

name: new_york
sentence: From about 1640 to 1680, the Iroquoian peoples conducted campaigns from modern Michigan to Virginia against the Algonquian and Siwan tribes, as well as against each other.

name: new_york
sentence: The goal was to control more land for trapping animals, a career that most Aboriginal people had turned to in the hope of trading with whites first.

name: new_york
sentence: This completely changed the ethnography of the region, and most of the big game was hunted before the whites fully exploded the land.

name: new_york
sentence: Subsequently, the Iroquois Confederation provided shelter for refugees from the Mascoutin, Erie, Chononton, Tutelo, Saponi and Tuscarora nations.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 1700s, they also merged with the Mohawks during the Franco-Indian war and took to the remaining Susquehannock of Pennsylvania after they were decimated in the war.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of these other groups have mixed up until they cease to exist.

name: new_york
sentence: Then, after the Revolution, a large group of them separated and returned to Ohio, becoming known as Mingo Senatorca.

name: new_york
sentence: The six current tribes of the Iroquois Confederation are the Senatorca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Tuscarora and Mohawk.

name: new_york
sentence: The Iroquois fought for both sides during the revolutionary war

name: new_york
sentence: Today, the Iroquois still live on several reserves in northern New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Meanwhile, the Lenapes formed a close relationship with William Penn.

name: new_york
sentence: However, when Penn died, his sons managed to take over much of their land and banish it to Ohio.

name: new_york
sentence: When the United States drafted the Indian Removal Act, the Lenapes were moved to Missouri, while their cousins, the Mohicans, were sent to Wisconsin.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition, in 1778, the United States relocated the Nanticoke from the Delmarva Peninsula to the former Iroquois lands south of Lake Ontario, although they did not stay long.

name: new_york
sentence: They mainly chose to migrate to Canada and merge with the Iroquois, although some moved westward and merged with the Lenapes.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1524 Giovanni da Verrazzano, an Italian explorer serving the French crown, explored the Atlantic coast of North America between the Carolinas and Newfoundland, including the port of New York and Narragansett Bay.

name: new_york
sentence: On 17 April 1524 Verrazzano entered New York Bay, passing through the strait now called the Narrows in the north bay which he named Santa Margherita, in honour of the sister of the king of France.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano described it as "a vast coastline with a deep delta in which each type of ship could pass" and added: "that it extends inland for a league and opens to form a beautiful lake.

name: new_york
sentence: This vast water table warmed up with native boats."

name: new_york
sentence: It landed on Manhattan's tip and maybe on the furthest point of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano's stay was interrupted by a storm that pushed him north towards Martha's Vineyard.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1540, French traders from New France built a castle on Castle Island in the present Albany; it was abandoned the following year due to flooding.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1614 the Dutch, under the command of Hendrick Corstiaensen, rebuilt the French castle which they called Fort Nassau.

name: new_york
sentence: Fort Nassau is the first Dutch settlement in North America and is located along the Hudson River, also in the present Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: The small fort served as a trading post and warehouse.

name: new_york
sentence: Located on the floodplain of the Hudson River, the rudimentary "strong" was swept away by the floods in 1617, and abandoned for good after the construction of Fort Orange, Newfoundland, near 1623.

name: new_york
sentence: Henry Hudson's voyage in 1609 marked the beginning of European engagement in the region.

name: new_york
sentence: Sailing for the Dutch East India Company and in search of a passage to Asia, he entered Upper New York Bay on September 11 of the same year.

name: new_york
sentence: His findings encouraged Dutch merchants to explore the coast in search of a profitable fur trade with local American Aboriginal tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 17th century, Dutch trading posts were created for the trade of skins from the Lenape, Iroquois and other tribes in the colony of New Netherlands.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of these trading posts was Fort Nassau (1614, near the present Albany); Fort Orange (1624, on the Hudson River, just south of the present city of Albany and created to replace Fort Nassau), developing into Beverwijck settlement (1647), and in what became Albany; Fort Amsterdam (1625, to become the city of New Amsterdam which is now New York City); and Esopus (1653, now Kingston).

name: new_york
sentence: The success of Rensselaerswyck (1630), which surrounded Albany and lasted until the mid-19th century, was also a key factor in the colony's initial success.

name: new_york

sentence: The city of New York was taken over by the Dutch in 1673 during the Third Anglo-Dutch War (1672–74) and renamed New Orange.

name: new_york
sentence: The Sons of Liberty were organized in New York during the 1760s, largely in response to the oppressive Stamp Act passed by the British Parliament in 1765.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Congress met in the city on 19 October of the same year, composed of representatives of all thirteen colonies that paved the way for the Continental Congress.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Act Congress resulted in the Bill of Rights and Grievances, which was the first written expression by American representatives of many rights and complaints later expressed in the United States Declaration of Independence.

name: new_york
sentence: This included the right to representative government.

name: new_york
sentence: At the same time, given the strong commercial, personal and sentimental ties with Britain, many New Yorkers were loyalists.

sentence: The capture of Fort Ticonderoga provided the gun and powder needed to force a British withdrawal from the siege of Boston in 1775.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the only colony not to vote for independence, as delegates were not allowed to do so.

name: new_york
sentence: New York then approved the Declaration of Independence on 9 July 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New York was conceived by a convention that met in White Plains on July 10, 1776, and after repeated adjournments and change of location, concluded its work in Kingston on Sunday evening, April 20, 1777, when the new constitution drafted by John Jay was adopted with a single dissenting voice.

name: new_york
sentence: It has not been submitted to the people for ratification.

name: new_york
sentence: On 30 July 1777 George Clinton was inaugurated as the first governor of New York City in Kingston.

name: new_york
sentence: About one third of the battles of the American Revolutionary War took place in New York; the first major (and largest of the whole war) was the Battle of Long Island, alias.

sentence: Battle of Brooklyn, August 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: After their victory, the British occupied the city of New York, making it their military and political base of operations in North America throughout the conflict and, therefore, the centre of interest of General George Washington's intelligence network.

name: new_york
sentence: Of the famous British prison ships in Wallabout Bay, more American fighters died of intentional negligence than they were killed in combat in every battle of the combined war.

name: new_york
sentence: Both combatant camps lost more soldiers than wounded.

sentence: New York became the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on 26 July 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: In an attempt to maintain sovereignty and remain an independent nation positioned between the new United States and British North America, four of the Iroquois nations fought on the British side; only the Oneidas and their dependents, the Tuscaroras, joined the Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: In retaliation for the border attacks by Mohawk forces Joseph Brant and Loyalist, the Sullivan Expedition of 1779 destroyed nearly 50 Iroquois villages, adjacent farmland and winter shops, forcing many refugees to travel to Niagara, under British control.

name: new_york
sentence: As British allies, the Iroquois were forced to leave New York, although they did not participate in treaty negotiations.

name: new_york
sentence: They moved to Canada after the war and received land concessions from the Crown.

name: new_york
sentence: In the settlement of the treaty, the British ceded most Indian lands to the new United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Because New York entered into a treaty with the Iroquois without Congress' approval, some of the land purchases have been the subject of land claims since the late 20th century by the tribes recognized by the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has sold more than 5 million acres (20,000 km2) of former Iroquois territory in the years following the revolutionary war, leading to rapid development in northern New York.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the Treaty of Paris, the last vestige of British authority in the Thirteen former colonies – their troops in New York – left in 1783, which was long celebrated as a day of evacuation.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the national capital under the statutes of Confederation and the perpetual Union, the first national government.

name: new_york
sentence: This organization was found to be inadequate, and prominent New Yorker Alexander Hamilton advocated a new government that would include executive power, national courts and the power to impose.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton led the Annapolis Convention (1786), which called for the Philadelphia Convention, which drafted the United States Constitution, in which he also participated.

name: new_york
sentence: The new government had to be a strong federal national government to replace the relatively weaker confederation of the different states.

name: new_york
sentence: Following a lively debate, which included the publication of the constitutional interpretation now quintessence – The Federalist Papers – as a series of articles in the New York newspapers, New York was the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on July 26, 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: New York remained the national capital under the new constitution until 1790 and was the site of the inauguration of President George Washington, the drafting of the United States Bill of Rights and the first session of the United States Supreme Court.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton's recovery of the highly indebted US economy after the war and the establishment of a national bank have greatly contributed to making New York the financial centre of the new nation.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch and British imported African slaves as workers into the city and colony; New York had the second largest slave population after Charleston, South Carolina.

name: new_york
sentence: Slavery was widespread in New York and in some agricultural areas.

name: new_york
sentence: The state passed a law for the progressive abolition of slavery shortly after the revolutionary war, but the last slave in New York was not released until 1827.

name: new_york
sentence: Transportation in western New York was carried out by expensive cars on muddy roads before the canals opened up rich agricultural land for long distances.

name: new_york
sentence: Governor DeWitt Clinton promoted the Erie Canal, which connects New York to the Great Lakes through the Hudson River, the new canal, and rivers and lakes.

name: new_york
sentence: Work began in 1817 and the Erie Canal opened in 1825.

name: new_york
sentence: Packages drawn by horses on towing routes moved slowly over the canal, carrying passengers and goods.

name: new_york
sentence: Agricultural products came from the Midwest and finished manufactured products moved westward.

name: new_york
sentence: It was a wonder of engineering that opened large areas of New York to commerce and colonization.

name: new_york
sentence: It has enabled port cities in the Great Lakes such as Buffalo and Rochester to grow and prosper.

name: new_york
sentence: It has also linked the emerging agricultural production of the Midwest and navigation on the Great Lakes to the port of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Improved transportation has led to increased migration of the population to the territories west of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: After 1850, the railways largely replaced the canal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was an important seaport and had significant trafficking in cotton imports from the South and exports of manufactured goods.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the early 19th century, New York has been the largest port of entry for legal immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: In the United States, the federal government assumed direct jurisdiction over immigration only in 1890.

name: new_york
sentence: Prior to that date, the matter was delegated to the various states and then by contract between the states and the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: Most immigrants to New York would land on busy docks along the Hudson and East Rivers in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: On May 4, 1847, the Legislative Assembly of New York State established the Council of Immigration Commissioners to regulate immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: The first permanent immigration depot in New York was established in 1855 at Castle Garden, a fort converted from the War of 1812 in what is now Battery Park, at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The first immigrants to arrive at the new depot were aboard three vessels that had just been released from quarantine.

name: new_york
sentence: Castle Garden was the deposit of immigrants from New York until its closure on April 18, 1890, when the federal government took control of immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: Over this period, more than eight million immigrants crossed its doors (two out of three American immigrants).

name: new_york
sentence: When the federal government took control, it created the Immigration Bureau, which chose the three-acre Ellis Island in the Upper New York Harbour for an entry depot.

name: new_york
sentence: Already under federal control, the island had been used as an ammunition depot.

name: new_york
sentence: It was chosen because of its relative isolation from the proximity of New York City and the railway lines of Jersey City, New Jersey, by a short ferry ride.

name: new_york
sentence: While the island was being developed and expanded through land rehabilitation, the federal government operated a temporary storage facility at the Barge Battery Office.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island opened its doors on January 1, 1892 and served as a central immigration centre until the passage of the National Origins Act in 1924, thereby reducing immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: After that date, the only immigrants to pass were displaced persons or war refugees.

name: new_york
sentence: The island ceased all immigration treatment on 12 November 1954, when the last person detained on the island, Norwegian sailor Arne Peterssen, was released.

name: new_york
sentence: He had exceeded his shore leave and had left the 10:15 a.m. ferry towards Manhattan to return to his ship.

name: new_york
sentence: Over 12 million immigrants passed through Ellis Island between 1892 and 1954.

name: new_york
sentence: More than one hundred million Americans across the United States can trace their ancestry to these immigrants.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island has been the subject of a long-standing dispute between the State of New York and the State of New Jersey, as both claimed.

name: new_york
sentence: The issue was settled in 1998 by the United States Supreme Court, which ruled that the original island of 3.3 acres (1.3 ha) was the territory of New York State and that the balance of 27.5 acres (11 ha) added after 1834 per landfill was in New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: The island was added to the national park service system in May 1965 by President Lyndon B. Johnson and is still owned by the federal government as part of the Statue of Liberty National Monument.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island was opened to the public as an immigration museum in 1990.

sentence: On September 11, 2001, two of the four hijacked aircraft were stolen from the original World Trade Center Twin Towers in Lower Manhattan, and the towers collapsed.

sentence: 7 World Trade Center also collapsed due to fire damage.

sentence: The other buildings of the World Trade Center complex were damaged beyond repairs and demolished shortly thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: The collapse of the twin towers caused considerable damage and resulted in 2,753 deaths, 147 of which were on board the two aircraft.

name: new_york
sentence: Since September 11, most of Lower Manhattan has been restored.

name: new_york
sentence: Over the past few years, more than 7,000 rescue workers and residents of the region have contracted a number of life-threatening diseases, some of which have died.

name: new_york
sentence: A memorial on the site, the National 11 September Memorial & Museum, was opened to the public on 11 September 2011.

sentence: A permanent museum opened on March 21, 2014.

sentence: From 2006 to 2018, 3 World Trade Center, 4 World Trade Center, 7 World Trade Center, World Trade Center Transportation Hub, Liberty Park and Fiterman Hall were completed.

sentence: The St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church and the Ronald O. Perelman Performing Arts Centre are under construction at the World Trade Center.

name: new_york
sentence: On October 29 and 30, 2012, Hurricane Sandy caused massive destruction on the shores of the state, ravaging parts of New York City, Long Island and South Westchester with record storm surges, severe flooding and violent winds causing power outages for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, resulting in fuel shortages and disruptions to public transit systems.

name: new_york
sentence: The storm and its deep effects led to discussions on the construction of sea walls and other coastal barriers around the shores of New York City and Long Island in order to minimize the risk of another such event.

name: new_york
sentence: This risk is considered highly probable due to global warming and sea level rise.

name: new_york
sentence: On March 1, 2020, New York had its first confirmed case of VOCID-19.

sentence: Since 28 March, New York has had the largest number of confirmed cases from any state in the United States.

sentence: Nearly 50 per cent of known national cases were in the state, with one third of known American cases in New York.
