sentence: In 2010, North Carolina's total gross national product was $424.9 billion, while public debt in November 2012, according to one source, was $2.4 billion, while another, according to another source, was $57.8 billion in 2012.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2011, the civilian labour force was about 4.5 million with a job close to 4.1 million.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is the first state in the United States in the production of tobacco and sweet potatoes, and comes second in the production of pigs and pigs, trout and turkeys.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the three most recent USDA surveys (2002, 2007, 2012), North Carolina also ranked second in the production of Christmas trees.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 15 metropolitan areas, and in 2010 was selected as the third best for business by Forbes Magazine, and the second best for business by Chief Executive Officer Magazine.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since 2000, economic growth in the urban and rural areas of North Carolina has been significantly divided.

name: north_carolina
sentence: While the urban areas of North Carolina have experienced a prosperous economy with steady employment growth, low unemployment and rising wages, many rural counties in the state have suffered from job losses, increased poverty and population loss as their manufacturing base has declined.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It is estimated that half of North Carolina's 100 counties have lost population since 2010, mainly due to the weak economy in many rural areas of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, the population of urban areas of the State continues to grow.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Residents of North Carolina have a life expectancy below the national average of life expectancy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: According to the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, in 2014, North Carolina men lived on average 75.4 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In North Carolina, females lived an average of 80.2 years, compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Men's life expectancy in North Carolina between 1980 and 2014 increased by an average of 6.9 years, compared to the national average of 6.7 years of increase in men's life expectancy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The life expectancy of women in North Carolina between 1980 and 2014 increased by 4.0 years, the same as the national average of 4.0 years in the life expectancy of women.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Using 2016-17 data, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation calculated that life expectancy in North Carolina counties ranged from 73.2 years in Robeson County to 82.1 years in Orange County.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The life expectancy of both sexes in the state was 78.0 years compared to 78.7 years for the United States as a whole.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina transportation systems include air, water, road, rail and public transportation, including the long distance railway via Amtrak and the light rail in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has the second largest state road network in the country as well as the largest ferry network on the east coast.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina airports serve destinations across the United States and international destinations in Canada, Europe, Central America and the Caribbean.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, Charlotte Douglas International Airport, the second largest business centre of American Airlines, ranked 23rd in the world.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has an expanding passenger rail network, with Amtrak serving most major cities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte is also home to the only light rail system in North Carolina known as Lynx.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The North Carolina government is divided into three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These include the Council of State (led by the Governor), the Bicameral Parliament (called the General Assembly) and the State Courts System (led by the Supreme Court of North Carolina).

name: north_carolina
sentence: The constitution of the State defines the structure and function of the government of the State.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 13 seats in the United States House of Representatives and two seats in the United States Senate.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The loyalties of the North Carolina party have undergone a series of significant changes in recent years: while the mid-term elections of 2010 saw Tar Heel voters elect for the first time in more than a century a bicameral republican majority, North Carolina has also become a turning state of the South in presidential races.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since the comfortable victory of Southern Democrat Jimmy Carter in the state in 1976, the state had always ruled Republican in presidential elections until Democratic Barack Obama narrowly won the state in 2008.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the 1990s, Democrat Bill Clinton reached a point of winning the state in 1992 and lost the state only narrowly in 1996.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the early 2000s, Republican George W. Bush easily won the state by more than 12 points.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2008, demographic changes, population growth and increased liberalization in densely populated areas such as the Research Triangle, Charlotte, Greensboro, Winston-Salem, Fayetteville and Asheville propelled Barack Obama to victory in North Carolina, the first democrat to win the state since 1976.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2012, North Carolina was once again considered a competitive swing state, with Democrats even holding their 2012 national democratic convention in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, Republican Mitt Romney finally won a two-point victory in North Carolina, the only swing state in 2012 Obama lost, and one of the only two states (with Indiana) to return from Obama in 2008 to the GOP in 2012.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2012, the state elected a Republican Governor (Pat McCrory) and a Lieutenant Governor (Dan Forest) for the first time in more than two decades, while giving Republicans veto-proof majorities to the House of State Representatives and the State Senator.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Several seats in the United States House of Representatives overturned control in 2012, with the Republicans holding nine seats for the four Democrats.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2014, Republican David Rouzer won the seventh seat of the state district, increasing the division of the Congress delegation to 10-3 in favour of the GOP.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The North Carolina Republicans won 10 of the 13 seats in 2016, when the Democrats won 47 percent of the votes in the state as a whole.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2018 the Republicans took nine, with an undecided seat, even though the Democrats won 48 percent of the total vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The indecisive election in the 9th district of the North Carolina Congress was due to the fact that the State Electoral Council refused in February 2019 to certify the results, after an investigation found evidence of widespread fraud against ballots by Republican members.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Democrats have been under-represented in state and congressional delegations since 2012, although they sometimes represent more than half of the population of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state has been prosecuted for racially waging the districts, which has led to the dilution of minority electoral power in some areas, resulting in misrepresentation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Federal Court ordered the redistribution in 2015.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Two trials contesting the map of the district of the Congress of State were conducted by "two dozen voters, the State Democratic Party, the State Chapter of the League of Women Electors, and the Joint Cause Interest Group".

name: north_carolina
sentence: They argue that the redistribution resulted in a deliberate under-representation of a significant portion of voters.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This case reached the U.S. Supreme Court in March 2019, which also heard a partisan case from Gerrymandering of Maryland.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Public primary and secondary schools are overseen by the North Carolina Department of Public Education.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Superintendent of Public Education of North Carolina is the Secretary of the North Carolina Council of State for Education, but the Council, rather than the Superintendent, holds most of the legal authority for the development of public education policy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2009, the chairman of the council also became the "Director General" of the State school system.

sentence: North Carolina has 115 public school systems, each of which is supervised by a local school board.

sentence: A county may have one or more systems inside.

sentence: The largest school systems in North Carolina are the Wake County Public School System, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, Guilford County Schools, Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Schools and Cumberland County Schools.

sentence: In total, there are 2,425 public schools in the State, including more than 200 charter schools.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The North Carolina schools were separated until the Brown v. Board of Education trial and the release of the Pearsall Plan.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1795, North Carolina opened the first public university in the United States, the University of North Carolina (now the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill).

name: north_carolina
sentence: More than 200 years later, the University of North Carolina system includes 17 public universities, including North Carolina State University, North Carolina A&T State University, North Carolina Central University, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, the University of North Carolina, the University of North Carolina, the University of Winston-Salem State University, the University of North Carolina at Asheville, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, the University of North Carolina at Pembroke, UNC Wilmington, Elizabeth City State University, Appalachian State University, Fayetteville State University and the UNC School of Arts.

name: north_carolina
sentence: With its public universities, North Carolina has 58 public community colleges in its community college system.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also home to many well-known private colleges and universities, including Duke University, Wake Forest University, Pfeiffer University, Lees-McRae College, Davidson College, Barton College, North Carolina Wesleyan College, Elon University, Guilford College, Livingstone College, Salem College, Shaw University (the first historically black college or university in the South), Laurel University, William Peace University, Meredith College, Methodist University, Belmont Abbey College (the only Catholic college in the Carolinas), Campbell University, University of Mount Olive, Montreat College, High Point University, Lenoir-Rhyne University (the only Lutheran university in North Carolina) and Wingate University.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has four major sports franchises: the National Football League's Carolina Panthers, the National Basketball Association's Charlotte Hornets and Major Football League's FC Charlotte are based in Charlotte, while the Raleigh's Carolina Hurricanes play in the National Hockey League.

sentence: Panthers and Hurricanes are the only two large professional sports teams that have the same geographical designation while playing in different metropolitan areas.

sentence: The Hurricanes are the only major professional team in North Carolina to have won a league championship, after winning the Stanley Cup in 2006.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also home to two other top professional teams in smaller sports: the Charlotte Hounds of Major League Lacrosse and the North Carolina Courage of the National Women's Soccer League.

sentence: Although North Carolina does not have a Major League baseball team, it has many minor League baseball teams, with the highest level of play from Charlotte Knights and Durham Bulls affiliated to the AA.

sentence: North Carolina offers a wide range of recreational activities, from swimming to the beach to skiing in the mountains.

sentence: North Carolina has theme parks, aquariums, museums, historic sites, lighthouses, elegant theatres, concert halls and refined restaurants.

sentence: North Carolina has traditions in art, music and cooking.

sentence: The non-profit arts and culture industry generates $1.2 billion in direct economic activity in North Carolina, supporting over 43,600 full-time equivalent jobs and generating $119 million in revenues for local governments and the state of North Carolina.

sentence: North Carolina has a large number of remarkable jazz musicians, some of whom are among the most important in the history of the genre.

Fletcher Opera Institute of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, the Department of Music at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill and the UNC Greensboro.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a state in the Midwest of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It bears the names of the indigenous tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which make up a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in the region, the fourth least populated, and the fourth least populated of the 50 States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck, and its largest city is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on 2 November 1889, as well as its neighbouring state, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th States admitted to union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison modified the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For convenience, both states are officially numbered in alphabetical order.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, the natural resources of North Dakota played a major role in its economic performance, particularly with the extraction of oil from the Bakken Formation, which is located under the northwestern part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This has led to population growth and a reduction in unemployment, resulting in North Dakota having the second lowest unemployment rate in the nation (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the highest artificial structure in the western hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the Upper Midwest region of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is located in the centre of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic center of North America is close to the city of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota, and Fargo is the largest city.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soil is the most valuable resource in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the basis of the state's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has huge mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tons of lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large oil reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered in the state in 1951 and quickly became one of the most valuable mineral resources in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing technologies allowed mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the formation of Bakken shale rocks in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota economy is based more on agriculture than most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota plants process agricultural products or manufacture agricultural equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many state merchants are also dependent on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover most of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They extend from the flat valley of the Red River to the east, through the hilly plains, to the rugged Badlands to the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main crop, wheat, is grown in almost all counties.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 per cent of Canada's canola and flaxseed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the country's leading producer of barley and sunflower and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers arrived in the North Dakota area before the 1870s because the railways had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 1870s, the North Pacific Railway began to cross Dakota territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale agriculture also began in the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern societies and some families have established huge wheat farms covering vast tracts of land in the Red River Valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made huge profits that they were called Bonanza Farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of the Bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1870, there were 2,405 people in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1890, the population had increased to 190,983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was named for the Sioux people who once lived on the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux were called Dakota or Lakota, meaning allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of the nicknames of North Dakota is the Peace Garden State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname honours the International Garden of Peace, located on the state border with Manitoba, in Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also called the state of Flickr because of the numerous land squirrels (Richardson land squirrels) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the U.S. region known as Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Northern Red River with Minnesota to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is to the south, Montana to the west, and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located near the centre of North America, with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota, which marks the "Geographic Centre of the North American Continent".

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2), including 178,712 square kilometres, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the great hilly plains as well as the northern part of the Badlands, which are west of the Missouri River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The highest point of the state, White Butte at 3506 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is abundant in fossil fuels, including natural gas, crude oil and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Lake Sakakawea, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the Garrison Dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central region of the state is divided into the Drift Prairie and the Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat valley of the Red River, the bottom of glacial lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the Red River that winds north into Lake Winnipeg, supports a large agricultural industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Devils Lake, the largest natural lake in the state, is also to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most of the state is covered by grasslands

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees are usually found in North Dakota where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil Lake, in the dunes of McHenry County in central North Dakota, and along the slopes of the Sheyenne Valley and Sheyenne Delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This diverse land is home to nearly 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a continental climate with warm summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Temperature differences are significant due to its remote interior position and being at the centre of the Northern Hemisphere, with distances approximately equal to the North Pole and the equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Amerindian peoples lived in what is now North Dakota for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (about the 11th century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both gathered in villages on the tributaries of the Missouri River in what was to become the western centre of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians traveled the western plains to visit and trade with related Hidatas after the split, probably in the seventeenth century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came the divisions of the Dakota people – Lakota, Santee and Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crees of Assiniboine and Plains made journeys southward to the Indians of the village, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shoshone Indians in current Wyoming and Montana may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of land houses at the bottom of the Sheyenne River (site of Biesterfeldt) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As a result of the attacks by the Crees, Assiniboines and Chippewas armed with firearms, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Sotaio Indians lived east of the Missouri River and met the uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They soon followed the Cheyennes through Missouri and lived among them south of the Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Finally, the Cheyennes and the Sutaio became a tribe and became hunters of buffaloes with ranges mainly outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the middle of the 19th century, the Arikara entered the future southern state and joined Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over time, a number of Indians entered into treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many treaties define the territory of a particular tribe (see map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to reach the region was the French-Canadian merchant Pierre Gaultier, Sieur de La Vérendrye, who led an exploration and trade team in the villages of Mandan in 1738.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, the region was part of the Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Europeans did not settle in Dakota until the end of the 19th century, when railways opened the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of land concessions, they vigorously market their properties, exalting the region as the ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On February 22, 1889, Congress passed an omnibus bill on state status for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington, entitled the Enabling Act of 1889, under the administration of President Grover Cleveland.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations that officially admitted North Dakota and South Dakota to the Union on November 2, 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new States presented a dilemma that must first be admitted to exist.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison ordered Secretary of State James G. Blaine to mix the papers and obscure the documents he signed first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The order was not recorded, so no one knows which Dakotas were admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, since North Dakota appears alphabetically before South Dakota, its proclamation was first published in the At Large Statutes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The carelessness of wheat producers, especially Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the Non-partisan League (NPL) around the First World War.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The NPL presented candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged into the Democratic Party after the Second World War).

name: north_dakota
sentence: He tried to isolate North Dakota from the power of banks and out-of-state companies.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both are still in place), NPL established a state railway line (later sold to Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-society laws virtually prohibited a corporation or bank from owning title to land delimited as agricultural land.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These laws, still in force today, after being confirmed by the state and federal courts, make it almost impossible to seize agricultural land, because even after the seizure, the title to property cannot be held by a bank or a mortgage company.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, the North Dakota Bank, with powers similar to those of a Federal Reserve bank, exercised its power to limit the issuance of mortgages at risk and their guarantee in the form of derivative instruments, thereby preventing the collapse of housing prices in the state following the 2008 financial crisis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The original North Dakota Capitol in Bismarck burned on the ground on December 28, 1930.

sentence: It was replaced by an art deco skyscraper with limestone facets that still stands today.

sentence: A series of federal investment and construction projects began in the 1950s, including the garrison dam and the bases of the Minot and Grand Forks Air Force.

sentence: Western North Dakota experienced an increase in oil exploration in the late 1970s and early 1980s, with rising oil prices making development profitable.

name: north_dakota

name: north_dakota
sentence: In recent years, the State has registered unemployment rates below the national average and has increased employment and population growth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Estimates of the remaining amount of oil in the region vary, some of which are estimated to be over 100 years old.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For decades, the annual North Dakota murder rate and violent crime rate were consistently lowest in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, in recent years, although still below the national average, crime has increased sharply.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the violent crime rate was three times higher than in 2004, with the increase occurring mainly in the late 2000s, coinciding with the oil boom era.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This occurred at a time when the national rate of violent crime slightly decreased.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Workers in oil boom cities were blamed for much of the increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the North Dakota population was 762,062 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 13.30 per cent over the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This makes North Dakota the U.S. state with the highest percentage of population growth since 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the fourth least populated state in the country; only Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1870, the North Dakota population increased by less than 2,000 to nearly 680,000 by 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Growth then slowed and the population fluctuated slightly over the last seven decades, reaching 617,761 people in the 1970 census, of whom 642,200 in the 2000 census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the exception of Amerindians, the North Dakota population has a lower percentage of minorities than the nation as a whole.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the second half of the 19th century and until the beginning of the 20th century, North Dakota, as well as most of the Midwest, experienced a massive influx of newcomers from the eastern United States and immigrants from Europe.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was a popular destination known to immigrant farmers and workers in general and their families, mainly Norway, Iceland, Sweden, Germany and the United Kingdom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of this colony was on the west side of the Red River Valley, as seen in South Dakota and parallel in Minnesota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This region is well known for its fertile land.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of World War I, it was one of the richest agricultural areas in North America.

name: north_dakota
sentence: But a period of higher rainfall ended, and many migrants did not succeed in arid conditions.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many family plots were too small to be successfully exploited.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Between the 1930s and the end of the 20th century, the North Dakota population declined gradually, interrupted by a few brief increases.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Young adults with a university degree were particularly likely to leave the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advance of the process of mechanization of agricultural practices, and the environmental conditions requiring more important land for successful agriculture, subsistence farming has proved too risky for families.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many people moved to urban areas to find a job.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since the end of the 20th century, one of the main causes of migration from North Dakota has been the lack of skilled jobs for college graduates.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The expansion of economic development programs has been encouraged to create skilled and high-tech jobs, but the effectiveness of these programs has been subject to debate.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During the first decade of the 21st century, the population increased largely due to employment in the oil industry related to the development of tight oil fields (shale oil).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Elsewhere, the Amerindian population has increased, with some reserves attracting people from urban areas.

name: north_dakota

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is one of the main places where refugees are resettled proportionally.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the United States Office of Refugee Resettlement, in 2013-2014, "more than 68 refugees" per 100,000 North Dakota were settled in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During fiscal year 2014, 582 refugees settled in the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo Mayor Mahoney said the acceptance of North Dakota by the largest number of refugees per capita should be celebrated given the benefits they bring to the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2015, Lutheran Social Services of North Dakota, the only government resettlement agency, received $458,090 in federal funding to improve refugee services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 3,323 people, and internal migration resulted in a net loss of 21,110 people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the North Dakota population, 69.8 per cent were born in North Dakota, 27.2 per cent were born in another state, 0.6 per cent were born in Puerto Rico, the American islands or abroad to American parents, and 2.4 per cent were born in another country.

sentence: The distribution by age and sex is approximate to the national average.

sentence: According to the 2010 census, the racial and ethnic composition of North Dakota was as follows:

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the mid-19th century, the territory of Dakota was still dominated by Amerindians.

name: north_dakota
sentence: War and disease reduced their population at the same time as Europeans and Americans settled in the state.

sentence: In the 21st century, most of the Northern Dakotas are of North European origin.

name: north_dakota

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has the most churches per capita in any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has the highest percentage of churches in any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to a 2001 survey, 35 per cent of the North Dakota population was Lutheran and 30 per cent Catholic.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other religious groups represented were Methodists (7%), Baptists (6%), God's Assemblies (3%), Presbyterians (1.27%) and Jehovah's Witnesses (1%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Christians with denominational or non-denominational affiliations, including other Protestants and the Church of Jesus Christ of the Last-Day Saints (LDS Church), totaled 3%, bringing the total Christian population to 86%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The number of Muslims is estimated at 920 and the number of Jews in the state at 730 in 2000.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Three per cent of respondents responded "without religion" to the survey, and six per cent refused to respond.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The largest church bodies by the number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 167,349; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 163,209; and the Lutheran Church – Synod of Missouri with 22,03.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 94.86% (584,496) of Northern Dakotans over 5 years of age spoke English as their main language.

name: north_dakota
sentence: 5.14% (31,684) of Northern Dakotas spoke a language other than English.

name: north_dakota
sentence: 1.39% (8,593) spoke German, 1.37% (8,432) Spanish and 0.30% (1,847) Norwegian.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other languages spoken include Serbo-Croatian (0.19%), Chinese and Japanese (0.15%), and Amerindian and French (0.13%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2000, 2.5% of the population spoke German in addition to English, reflecting the immigration of the early 20th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, North Dakota has an increasing population of Native Americans, accounting for 5.44% of the population in 2010.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of the 19th century, the territory was dominated by the Siwan-speaking peoples, whose territory extended west of the Great Lakes region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The word "Dakota" is a Sioux (Lakota/Dakota) meaning "allies" or "friends".

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major historical tribal nations of or around North Dakota are Lakota and Dakota ("The Sioux Great Nation" or "Oceti Sakowin", i.e. the seven lights of the council), Blackfoot, Cheyenne, Chippewa (known as Ojibwe in Canada) and Mandan.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The tribes recognized by the federal government have Indian reserves in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Social gatherings known as "powwows" (or wacipis in Lakota/Dakota) continue to be an important part of Amerindian culture and are held regularly throughout the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the history of the Amerindians, powwows were held, usually in spring, to rejoice at the beginning of the new life and the end of the winter cold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These events brought together Amerindian tribes to sing and dance and allowed them to meet and make new friends and acquaintances.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many powwows also had religious significance for some tribes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, powwows are still part of the Native culture and are frequented by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, the United Tribes International Powwow, held monthly in September in the capital of Bismarck, is one of the largest powwows in the United States.

name: north_dakota

sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', which means "good river," "great river," or "great river."

sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were contested from the colonial era through the Indian wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the resulting Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the North-West Ordinance.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power plants in the 20th century; although it has evolved to a more information- and service-oriented economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive, headed by the Governor; the legislature, composed of the Bicameral General Assembly of Ohio; and the judiciary, headed by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio holds 16 seats in the United States House of Representatives.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as both a pivotal state and a gazebo in national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents of the United States came from Ohio, the most of all states; this led to receiving the moniker "Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: The geographic location of Ohio has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio connects the northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic cross its borders along its well-developed roads.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive of 50% of the North American population and 70% of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing for many loading ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio boundary is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and much of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania to the east, Michigan to the northwest, Lake Erie to the north, Indiana to the west, Kentucky to the south, and West Virginia to the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio boundaries were defined in the enabling Act of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but almost the entire river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, based on the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and consequently West Virginia) is the north low water mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has only this part of the river between the 1792 low water mark and the current high water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The boundary with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to a slightly northeasterly angle to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glazed till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glaciated area in the northwest and central state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glaciated Allegheny plateau, then by another belt known as the unglaciated Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low relief, but the unglazed Allegheny Plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends into an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River, from the western part of Virginia Panhandle to the periphery of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, mining in that area, dependence on small pockets of former manufacturing facilities and the distinctive regional dialect put this section out of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, an attempt to "respond to the persistent poverty and growing economic despair of the Appalachian region".

name: ohio
sentence: This Act defines 29 Ohio counties as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While 1/3 of Ohio's land mass is in the Appalachian region defined by the federal government, only 12.8% of Ohio's people live there (1.476 million people).

name: ohio
sentence: Important rivers in the state include the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: Rivers in the northern part of the state flow through Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River in the northern Atlantic Ocean, and rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Gulf of Mexico via Ohio and then Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio's history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Dayton Great Flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including the business district of downtown Dayton.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was created as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Grand Lac St. Marys, located in the western central part of the state, was built as a source of water for canals during the construction of canals from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this stretch of water, more than 52 km2, was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio canal construction projects were not the economic fiasco that similar efforts were made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and until 1910 the inland canals carried much of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) in most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Ohio Bluegrass region, which are located on the northern periphery of the wet subtropical climate (Cfa) and the U.S. Upland South region.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid throughout the state, while winters generally vary from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Precipitation in Ohio is moderate all year round.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the Tornado gangway.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snowstorms are not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area designated as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although it is not primarily in a subtropical climate, some warmer species of fauna and flora reach Ohio well.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees with more southern ranges, such as Blackjack Oak, Quercus marilandica, are located northerly of Ohio, just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Several plants such as Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrisin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle and even occasionally Needle Palm are robust landscaping materials regularly used as street, courtyard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed by traveling across Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this diverse state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to flooding resulting in severely damaged roads, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 counties in Ohio in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113°F (45°C), near Gallipolis on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39°F (−39°C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899 during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few people have registered as being visible to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or more have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and numerous faults are located below the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest known earthquake in Ohio's history was the earthquake in Anna, Shelby County, on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centered in western Ohio, and had a magnitude of 5.4, and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; one of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township, Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, about 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northwest of Eastlake under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic centre of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other cities in Ohio operate as economic and cultural centres in metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield and Youngstown are in the northeast, known for the major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timber, the top-ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions including the Cleveland Art Museum, Big Five Group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the major cities in northwestern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwestern Ohio is known for its glass industry and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, home to Dayton University, Dayton Ballet, and the large base of the Wright-Patterson Air Force.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors southwestern Ohio and is the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, as well as various companies of Fortune 500 including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc. and the fifth third bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan city in Appalachian Ohio, home to Hocking Hills National Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends as far as Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends as far as West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends as far as Michigan, and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends as far as Pennsylvania.

name: ohio

name: ohio

name: ohio
sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: These first nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1,000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1,000 and 800 B.C., Adena's sedentary culture appeared.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn"; with hunting and gathering, this crop supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most remarkable remnant of Adena culture is the Grand Serpent Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 B.C., Adena evolved to the Hopewells, who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex, large-scale and technologically sophisticated earthworks are located in Marietta, Newark and Circleville today.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific commercial company, with their commercial network covering a third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: Hopewell disappeared from the Ohio Valley around 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: Mississippi culture developed as Hopewell culture declined.

name: ohio
sentence: Many peoples speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say that they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the 13th century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with the Mississippians: the ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: The three cultures disappeared in the 17th century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origins are unknown.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnees may have absorbed the people of the Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that Monongahela did not hold land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippi culture was close to the people of the Old Fort and was widely traded with them.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Valley Indians were greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the beaver wars in the mid-17th century, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, more importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the middle of the 17th century, which largely emptied the Ohio country from the indigenous populations in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land gradually became repopulated by the predominantly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio nations were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born of the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They remained in agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: supplemented by seasonal hunting.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger global economy created by Europe's entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: Indigenous nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians, and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was also the site of Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac Rebellion School massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of the Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually redeemed and convinced to leave, or ordered by law, at the beginning of the 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, the French introduced a system of trading posts to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: From 1754 on, France and Great Britain fought the French and Indian wars.

name: ohio
sentence: Following the Treaty of Paris, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris of 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the Northwest Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not permitted in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The settlement began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of veterans of the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Purchase of Symmes") claimed the southwest section, and the Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the Connecticut Western Reserve in the present northeast of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors at Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area of eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally included areas formerly known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, the Indiana Territory was created, reducing the Northwest Territory to about the present size of Ohio, plus half of the lower Michigan Peninsula and the eastern tip of the Upper Peninsula and a portion of the southeast Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: In 1795 the coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Western Confederation, was forced to cede a vast territory, including much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as States as soon as their population reached 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and that it had already begun to become a state.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would be "separated and that their property would be vested in the Moravian Brothers [...] or a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and promoting Christianity."

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served extensively in the French and Indian War and in the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men in the early years of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of building portable fortifications, which allowed the Continental Army to drive the British from Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he made Putnam his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the Northwest Order, which opened the Northwest Territory to colonization.

name: ohio
sentence: This land served as compensation for what was due to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also on the recommendation of Putam that the lands will be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans in the territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They moved to Marietta, Ohio, where they built a large fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the Northwest Territory be a free territory – no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and the Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally evil.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States and declared it slavery-free was of considerable importance in the following decades.

name: ohio
sentence: It includes what became Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had those states been slave states, and their electoral votes had been attributed to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: The civil war would not have been fought.

name: ohio
sentence: And, even if there had been a civil war, the North would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam, in Puritan tradition, played an important role in the establishment of education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Important land has been set aside for schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam had been one of the main benefactors of the founding of the Leicester Academy in Massachusetts, and in 1798 he also created the plan for the construction of the Muskingum Academy (now Marietta College) in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1780 the directors of the Ohio Company appointed him superintendent of all his settlement affairs north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1796 he was commissioned by President George Washington to be a surveyor general of the United States Lands.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1788 he was a judge at the first court of the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1802 he served in the assembly to form a constitution for the State of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: On February 19, 1803, U.S. President Thomas Jefferson signed a law of Congress that approved the limits and constitution of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: However, Congress had never adopted a resolution officially recognizing Ohio as the 17th state.

name: ohio
sentence: The current custom of Congress declaring an official date of the State did not begin until 1812, with the admission of Louisiana as the 18th state.

name: ohio
sentence: Although no formal admission resolutions were required, when surveillance was discovered in 1953, while Ohio was preparing to celebrate its sesquicentenary, the Ohio MP, George H. Bender, introduced to Congress a bill to admit Ohio to the Union retroactively to March 1, 1803, when the Ohio General Assembly met for the first time.

name: ohio
sentence: At a special session at the former state capital in Chillicothe, the Ohio State Legislative Assembly approved a new petition for the creation of a state that was handed over to Washington, D.C., on horseback.

name: ohio
sentence: On August 7, 1953 (the year of Ohio's 150th anniversary), President Eisenhower signed a joint Congress resolution that officially declared March 1, 1803, the date Ohio was admitted into the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has three capitals: Chillicothe, Zanesville and Columbus.

name: ohio
sentence: Chillicothe was the capital from 1803 to 1810.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then moved to Zanesville for two years, as part of a state legislative compromise to pass a bill.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then relocated to Chillicothe, which was the capital from 1812 to 1816.

name: ohio
sentence: Finally, the capital was moved to Columbus, to have it near the geographical center of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Although many Amerindians migrated westward to escape the encroachment of the Americans, others remained in the state, sometimes partially assimilated.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1830, under the leadership of President Andrew Jackson, the U.S. government forced the abduction of most tribes in Indian territory west of Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1835 Ohio fought with Michigan in the Toledo War, an almost bloodless border war on the Toledo Band.

name: ohio
sentence: Only one person was injured in the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: Congress intervened, making Michigan's admission as a conditional state at the end of the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: In exchange for the abandonment of its claim to the Toledo Band, Michigan received two-thirds west of the upper peninsula, in addition to one-third east that was already considered part of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: The central position of Ohio and its population gave it an important place during the civil war.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio River was a vital artery for troop and supply movements, as was the Ohio Railways.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio industry has made the state one of the most important states in the Union during the civil war.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has provided more soldiers per capita than any other state in the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1862, the morale of the state was severely shaken as a result of the battle of Shiloh, a costly victory in which the Ohio forces suffered 2,000 casualties.

name: ohio
sentence: Later that year, when the Confederate troops under Stonewall Jackson threatened Washington, D.C., Ohio Governor David Tod could still recruit 5,000 volunteers to provide three months of service.

name: ohio
sentence: From July 12 to 23, 1863, South Ohio and Indiana were attacked in Morgan's raid.

name: ohio
sentence: While this raid was insignificant and small, it aroused fear among the people of Ohio and Indiana.

name: ohio
sentence: Nearly 35,000 Ohioans died in the conflict and 30,000 were physically injured.

name: ohio
sentence: At the end of the civil war, the first three generals of the Union – Ulysses S. Grant, William Tecumseh Sherman and Philip Sheridan – were all from Ohio.

sentence: In addition, it allowed the General Assembly to ask questions about the vote in order for the people to ratify the laws and constitutional amendments emanating from the Legislative Assembly.

name: ohio
sentence: According to Jeffersonian's principle that laws should be reviewed once per generation, the constitution provided for a recurring issue to be included in the general election ballots of Ohio every 20 years.

name: ohio
sentence: The question arises as to whether a new convention is necessary.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the issue appeared in 1932, 1952, 1972 and 1992, it was never approved.

name: ohio
sentence: Instead, constitutional amendments were proposed by petition to the legislature hundreds of times and adopted in the majority of cases.

name: ohio
sentence: From 45,000 in 1800, Ohio's population grew more rapidly than 10% per decade (except for the 1940 census) until the 1970 census, which recorded just over 10.65 million Ohioans.

name: ohio

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is a state in the south-central United States, bordered by the state of Texas in the south and west, Kansas in the north, Missouri in the northeast, Arkansas in the east, New Mexico in the west, and Colorado in the northwest.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Partly in the extreme west of the South Uplands, it is the 20th largest and 28th most populous of the 50 United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its inhabitants are known as Oklahomans (or "Okies"), and its capital and largest city is Oklahoma City.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The name of the state is derived from the words of Choctaw okla and Humma, meaning "red people".

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is also known informally by its nickname, "The Sooner State", with reference to non-Aboriginal settlers who staked their land claims before the official date of land opening in western Oklahoma or before the Indian Credit Act, 1889, which increased Euro-American settlement in eastern Indian territory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The territory of Oklahoma and the Indian territory were merged into the State of Oklahoma when it became the 46th state to join the union on November 16, 1907.

sentence: With ancient mountain ranges, meadows, mesas and eastern forests, most of Oklahoma lies on the great plains, crosswoods and the United States.

sentence: Oklahoma is located on a confluence of three major American cultural regions and has historically served as a road for cattle hunting, a destination for southern settlers and a territory approved by the government for the Amerindians.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Twenty-five Amerindian languages are spoken in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: A major producer of natural gas, oil and agricultural products, Oklahoma is based on an economic base of aviation, energy, telecommunications and biotechnology.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The city of Oklahoma and Tulsa are the main economic anchors of Oklahoma, nearly two thirds of Oklahoma living in their metropolitan statistical areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The name Oklahoma comes from the language phrase of Choctaw okla humma, literally meaning red people.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Chief Choctaw Allen Wright suggested this name in 1866 during treaty negotiations with the federal government on the use of Indian territory, in which he envisaged a fully Indian state controlled by the Superintendent of Indian Affairs of the United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Equivalent to the Indian English word, okla humma was a sentence in the language of Choctaw describing the Amerindians as a whole.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma later became the de facto name of Oklahoma territory, and was officially approved in 1890, two years after the area was opened to white settlers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the language of Chickasaw, the state is known as Oklahomma', in Arapaho as bo'obe' (literally meaning red earth), Pawnee: Uukuhuúwa, and Cayuga: Gahnawiyo.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is the 20th state of the United States, covering an area of 281,040 km2, with 27,660 km2 of land and 3,380 km2 of water.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is found in part in the Great Plains near the geographical center of the 48 contiguous states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is bounded to the east by Arkansas and Missouri, to the north by Kansas, to the northwest by Colorado, to the extreme west by New Mexico, and to the south and near west by Texas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma lies between the Great Plains and the Ozark Plateau in the Gulf of Mexico watershed, generally sloping from the high plains of its western boundary to the low wetlands of its southeast boundary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its highest and lowest points follow this trend, with its highest summit, Black Mesa, 4,973 feet (1,516 m) above sea level, located near its very northwest corner in the Oklahoma Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The lowest point in the state is on the Little River, near its southeast boundary, near the town of Idabel, which descends 289 feet (88 m) above sea level.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Among the most geographically diverse states, Oklahoma is one of four that houses more than 10 distinct ecological regions, with 11 within its borders – more per square mile than in any other state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its western and eastern halves, however, are marked by extreme differences in geographical diversity: the eastern Oklahoma affects eight ecological regions and its western half contains three.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although having fewer ecological regions Western Oklahoma contains many rare, relic species.

sentence: Oklahoma has four main mountain ranges: Ouachita Mountains, Arbuckle Mountains, Wichita Mountains and Ozark Mountains.

sentence: The southwestern Oklahoma contains many rare and isolated species, including sugar maple, large-toned maple, nolina, and live Texas oak.

sentence: The state is home to populations of white-tailed deer, mule deer, antelope, coyotes, mountain lions, bobcats, elk and birds such as quail, doves, cardinals, bald eagles, red-tailed hawks and pheasants.

sentence: In prairie ecosystems, American bison, large Prairie chickens, badgers and armadillos are common, and some of the country's largest prairie dog cities inhabit short-grass prairies in the state panhandle.

sentence: Oklahoma has fifty-one state parks, six national parks or protected areas, two national protected forests or grasslands, and a network of wildlife reserves and conservation areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is in a wet subtropical region.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma occurs in a transition zone between semi-arid to the west, wet continental to the north, and wet subtropical to the east and south-east.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Most of the state is located in an area known as the Tornado Alley, characterized by frequent interaction between cold and dry air in Canada, hot hot air, dry air in Mexico and the southwestern United States, and warm and humid air in the Gulf of Mexico.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Interactions between these three contrasting air currents produce severe weather (serious thunderstorms, damaging storm winds, large hail and tornadoes) with an almost invisible frequency anywhere else on planet Earth.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On average, 62 tornadoes hit the state per year, one of the highest rates in the world.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Owing to the position of Oklahoma between zones of different temperatures and winds, weather conditions within the state can vary considerably over relatively short distances, and can change dramatically in a short time.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On November 11, 1911, the temperature in Oklahoma City reached 83°F (28°C) (the record of that date), then a cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed through the state, resulting in the temperature reaching 17°F (−8°C) (the record of that date) at midnight.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This type of phenomenon is also responsible for many tornadoes in the region, such as the Oklahoma tornado epidemic in 1912 when a warm front ran through a frozen cold front, resulting in an average of one tornado per hour.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The humid subtropical climate (Koppen Cfa) in central, southern and eastern Oklahoma is strongly influenced by southerly winds bringing moisture to the Gulf of Mexico.

name: oklahoma
sentence: To the west, climate transitions to a semi-arid area (Koppen BSk) in the Panhandle High Plains and other areas west of Lawton to the west, less frequently affected by southern moisture.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Precipitation and temperatures are decreasing from east to west as a result, with areas in the southeast having an average annual temperature of 62°F (17°C) and annual precipitation of more than 40" (1,020 mm) and up to 56" (1,420 mm), while areas in the panhandle (upper elevation) have an average of 58°F (14°C), with annual precipitation of less than 17" (430 mm).

name: oklahoma
sentence: mid-summer (July and August) represents a secondary dry season over much of Oklahoma, with long periods of warm weather with only sporadic stormy activity not uncommon for many years.

name: oklahoma

sentence: Residents of Oklahoma have lower than average life expectancy compared to many other states.

sentence: In 2014, men in Oklahoma lived on average 73.7 years, compared to 76.7 years on average, and women on average 78.5 years, compared to 81.5 years on average.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Transportation in Oklahoma is generated by an anchoring system of interstate highways, interurban railway lines, airports, inland ports and public transport networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 12,000 miles (19,000 km) of roads are the largest road skeleton in the state, including government-operated roads, ten tolls or major toll roads, and the longest section of Highway 66 in the nation.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
