sentence: June 19 commemorates the announcement of the proclamation of emancipation in Galveston by General Gordon Granger, almost two and a half years after the initial announcement.

name: texas
sentence: In 1866, President Johnson declared the civilian government re-established in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Although not responding to reconstruction needs, Congress resumed authorizing Texas officials elected to the federal government in 1870.

name: texas
sentence: Social volatility continued as the state struggled against agricultural depression and labour problems.

name: texas
sentence: Like most countries in the South, Texas's economy has been devastated by war.

name: texas
sentence: However, since the State had not been as dependent on slaves as other parts of the South, it was able to recover more quickly.

name: texas
sentence: In the 19th century, Texas's culture had many facets of a frontier territory.

name: texas
sentence: The state has become famous as a refuge for people from other parts of the country who wanted to escape debt, war tensions, or other problems.

name: texas
sentence: Indeed, "going to Texas" was a common expression for those fleeing the law in other states.

name: texas
sentence: Nevertheless, the state has also attracted many businessmen and other settlers with more legitimate interests.

name: texas
sentence: The beef industry has continued to thrive, although it has gradually become less profitable.

name: texas
sentence: Cotton and wood have become important industries that have created new economic booms in various parts of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Rail networks have grown rapidly, as has the port of Galveston, while trade between Texas and the rest of the United States (and the rest of the world) has grown.

name: texas
sentence: As in other states, the softwood lumber industry developed rapidly in Texas and was its largest industry before the beginning of the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: In 1900 Texas suffered the most deadly natural disaster in American history during the Galveston Hurricane.

name: texas
sentence: On January 10, 1901, Texas's first major oil well, Spindletop, was discovered south of Beaumont.

name: texas
sentence: Other fields were discovered near eastern Texas, western Texas, and under the Gulf of Mexico.

name: texas
sentence: The resulting oil boom transformed Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Oil production reached an average of 3 million barrels per day at its peak in 1972.

name: texas
sentence: In 1901, the predominantly democratic state parliament passed a bill requiring the payment of an electoral tax for voting, which effectively deprived most blacks and many poor whites and Latinos.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, the legislator has created white primaries, ensuring that minorities are excluded from the formal political process.

name: texas
sentence: The number of voters has fallen considerably, and the Democrats have crushed the competition of the Republican and populist parties.

name: texas
sentence: The Socialist Party became the second party in Texas after 1912, coinciding with a great socialist rise in the United States in fierce battles in the workers' movement and the popularity of national heroes like Eugene V. Debs.

name: texas
sentence: The popularity of the socialists quickly weakened after their denigration by the U.S. government for their opposition to the involvement of the U.S. in the First World War.

name: texas
sentence: The Great Depression and the Dust Bowl have done a double blow to the state economy, which had improved considerably since the civil war.

name: texas
sentence: Migrants left Texas's most affected neighbourhoods during the Dust Bowl years.

name: texas
sentence: Especially from that time on, Blacks left Texas in the Great Migration to work in the north of the United States or in California and to escape the oppression of segregation.

name: texas
sentence: In 1940, Texas was 74 percent Anglo, 14.4 percent Black and 11.5 percent Hispanic.

name: texas
sentence: The Second World War had a dramatic impact on Texas, while federal money was used to build military bases, ammunition factories, prison camps and army hospitals; 750,000 young men left for service; cities exploded with a new industry; colleges took on new roles; and hundreds of thousands of poor farmers left the fields for much better paid war jobs, never returning to agriculture.

name: texas
sentence: Texas manufactured 3.1 per cent of all U.S. military weapons produced during the Second World War, ranking 11th among the 48 states.

name: texas
sentence: Texas modernized and expanded its higher education system in the 1960s.

name: texas
sentence: The State has developed a comprehensive plan for higher education, largely financed by oil revenues, and a central government apparatus designed to manage State institutions more effectively.

name: texas
sentence: These changes have helped Texas universities receive federal funding for research.

name: texas
sentence: On November 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas.

name: texas
sentence: Starting in the mid-20th century, Texas began to transform a rural and agricultural state into an urban and industrialized state.

name: texas
sentence: The population of the State increased rapidly during this period, with high levels of migration from outside the State.

name: texas
sentence: As part of the Sun Belt, Texas experienced strong economic growth, particularly in the 1970s and early 1980s.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's economy has diversified, reducing its dependence on the oil industry.

name: texas
sentence: In 1990, Hispanics and Latin Americans surpassed Blacks and became the largest minority group in the state.

name: texas
sentence: At the end of the 20th century, the Republican Party replaced the Democratic Party as a dominant party in the state, the latter having become more politically liberal and as demographic changes favoured the former.

name: texas
sentence: Beginning in the early 21st century, metropolitan areas, including Dallas–Fort Worth and Greater Austin, became centres for the Texas Democratic Party throughout the state and national elections as liberal policies became more accepted in urban areas.

name: texas
sentence: On July 7, 2016, Dallas police officers were ambushed by Micah Xavier Johnson, killing five police officers and wounding nine others in retaliation against white police officers.

name: texas
sentence: Johnson was the first person suspected of being killed by a robot used by American law enforcement.

name: texas
sentence: From the mid-2000s to 2019, Texas gained an influx of corporate relocations and regional headquarters in California.

name: texas
sentence: Texas became a major destination for migration in the early 21st century and was named the most popular state to move for three consecutive years.

name: texas
sentence: Another study conducted in 2019 determined Texas's growth rate at 1,000 people per day.

name: texas
sentence: During the VOCID-19 pandemic in the United States, the first confirmed case of the virus in Texas was announced on March 4, 2020.

name: texas
sentence: As of December 28, 2020, 1.7 million cases had been confirmed in Texas, with at least 27,245 deaths.

name: texas
sentence: On April 27, 2020, Governor Greg Abbott announced the first phase of the reopening of the economy.

name: texas
sentence: The openings of the second phase began on 18 May and the third phase was announced on 3 June.

name: texas
sentence: Governor Abbott deplored the rapid reopening of bars during the VOCID-19 pandemic in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In the 2020 U.S. presidential election, Governor Abbott announced a controversial decision to limit the location of a postal ballot box for each county.

name: texas
sentence: Harris County, Texas, received national media attention because the county, which is larger than the size of Rhode Island and has 2.4 million registered voters, was served by only one polling box.

name: texas
sentence: A federal judge blocked the Governor's order until it was appealed to the court.

name: texas
sentence: Abbott was prosecuted by voters and voter rights groups following the order.

name: texas
sentence: In the context of an increase in VOCID-19 cases in the fall of 2020, Abbott refused to enact new locks.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is the second-largest American state, after Alaska, with an area of 696,200 km2.

name: texas
sentence: Although 10% more than France and almost twice as large as Germany or Japan and more than double the size of the United Kingdom, it is only 27th in the world among country subdivisions by size.

name: texas
sentence: If it were an independent country, Texas would be the 39th largest.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is located in the south-central United States of America.

name: texas
sentence: Three of its boundaries are defined by rivers.

name: texas
sentence: Rio Grande forms a natural border with the Mexican states of Chihuahua, Coahuila, Nuevo León and Tamaulipas to the south.

name: texas
sentence: The Red River forms a natural border with Oklahoma and Arkansas to the north.

name: texas
sentence: The Sabine River forms a natural boundary with Louisiana to the east.

name: texas
sentence: Texas Panhandle has an eastern border with Oklahoma at 100° W, a northern border with Oklahoma at 36° 30' N and a western border with New Mexico at 103° W. El Paso is located on the western tip of the state at 32° N and Rio Grande.

name: texas
sentence: With 10 climatic regions, 14 soil regions and 11 distinct ecological regions, regional classification becomes problematic due to differences in soils, topography, geology, precipitation, and plant and animal communities.

name: texas
sentence: A classification system divides Texas, in the order of southeast to west, with respect to the Gulf coastal plains, the inland lowlands, the Great Plains, and the province of the basin and range.

name: texas
sentence: The Gulf coastal plains region wraps around the Gulf of Mexico on the southeastern part of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The vegetation in this area consists of thick pine wood.

name: texas
sentence: The inland lowland region consists of hilly woodlands that form part of a larger pine and hardwood forest.

name: texas
sentence: The Cross Timbers area and the Caprock Escarpment are part of the inland lowlands.

name: texas
sentence: The Great Plains region in central Texas crosses the state panhandle and Llano Estacado to the country of the state hills near Austin.

name: texas
sentence: This area is dominated by grasslands and steppes.

name: texas
sentence: "Far West Texas" or "Trans-Pecos" is the province of the basin and range of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The most varied of the regions, this area includes Sand Hills, Stockton Plateau, desert valleys, mountain wooded slopes and desert meadows.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 3,700 streams and 15 main rivers, with Rio Grande being the largest.

name: texas
sentence: Other important rivers are Pecos, Brazos, Colorado and the Red River.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas has few natural lakes, the Texans have built more than a hundred artificial reservoirs.

name: texas
sentence: The size and unique history of Texas make its regional affiliation questionable; it can be considered a state of the South or Southwest, or both.

name: texas
sentence: The great geographical, economic and cultural diversity within the state itself prohibits the easy categorization of the entire state into a recognized region of the United States.

name: texas
sentence: Notable extremes range from eastern Texas, which is often considered an extension from the deep south to the extreme west of Texas, which is generally recognized as part of the inner southwest.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is the southernmost part of the Great Plains, which ends in the south against the folded Western Sierra Madre of Mexico.

name: texas
sentence: The continental crust forms a stable mesoproterozoic craton that transforms through a wide continental margin and a transient crust into a true oceanic crust of the Gulf of Mexico.

name: texas
sentence: The oldest rocks in Texas date from Mesoproterozoic and are about 1600 million years old.

name: texas
sentence: These igneous and metamorphic precambrian rocks underlie most of the state and are exposed in three places: the Llano Uprising, Van Horn and Franklin Mountains, near El Paso.

name: texas
sentence: Sedimentary rocks cover most of these ancient rocks.

name: texas
sentence: The oldest sediments were deposited on the sides of a torn continental margin, or passive margin that developed during Cambrian.

name: texas
sentence: This margin existed until Laurasia and Gondwana collided in the Pennsylvania subperiod to form Pangea.

name: texas
sentence: This is the buried ridge of the Appalachian Mountains – Pennsylvania Continental Collision Ouachita.

name: texas
sentence: This orogenous ridge is now buried under the Dallas–Waco–Austin–San Antonio trend.

name: texas
sentence: The end of the Paleozoic mountains collapsed as the Jurassic began to open the Gulf of Mexico.

name: texas
sentence: The Pangea began to break in the Triassic, but the sea floor extending to form the Gulf of Mexico only appeared in the middle and at the end of the Jurassic.

name: texas
sentence: The coastline moved back to the eastern margin of the state and the passive margin of the Gulf of Mexico began to form.

name: texas
sentence: Today, 14 to 19 km of sediment is buried under the Texas continental shelf and a large portion of the remaining U.S. oil reserves are here.

name: texas
sentence: At the beginning of its formation, the nascent basin of the Gulf of Mexico was restricted and seawater often evaporated completely to form thick evaporite deposits of the Jurassic age.

name: texas
sentence: These salt deposits form salt domes and are located in eastern Texas along the Gulf coast.

name: texas
sentence: Outcrops in eastern Texas consist of cretaceous and paleogenic sediments that contain significant deposits of eocene lignite.

name: texas
sentence: The Mississippi and Pennsylvania sediments in the north; the Permian sediments in the west; and the Cretaceous sediments in the east, along the Gulf coast, and on the Texas continental shelf contain oil.

name: texas
sentence: Oligocene volcanic rocks are found in the extreme west of Texas, in the Big Bend area.

name: texas
sentence: An important aquifer is a Miocene sediment cover known as the Ogallala Formation in the Western High Plains region.

name: texas
sentence: Located far from an active plate tectonic limit, Texas has no volcanoes and few earthquakes.

name: texas
sentence: A wide range of animals and insects live in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: It is home to 65 species of mammals, 213 species of reptiles and amphibians, and the largest diversity of bird life in the United States, 590 native species.

name: texas
sentence: At least 12 species have been introduced and now breed freely in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas hosts several species of wasps, including an abundance of Pole extamans, and is an important ground for the study of Ring Polists.

name: texas
sentence: In the spring, Texas wildflowers such as the State flower, the bluebonnet, the highways of the line throughout Texas.

name: texas
sentence: During the Johnson administration, the first lady, Lady Bird Johnson, worked to draw attention to the wildflowers of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The large size of Texas and its location at the intersection of several climatic zones give the state a very variable time.

name: texas
sentence: The state Panhandle has colder winters than northern Texas, while the Gulf coast has mild winters.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has large variations in precipitation.

name: texas
sentence: El Paso, at the western end of the state, has an average of 8.7 inches (220 mm) of annual precipitation, while parts of southeastern Texas have an average of 64 inches (1,600 mm) per year.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas in the North Central Region has a more moderate average of 37 inches (940 mm) per year.

name: texas
sentence: Snow falls several times each winter in the Panhandle and mountainous areas of western Texas, once or twice a year in northern Texas, and once every few years in central and eastern Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Snow falls south of San Antonio or on the coast only in rare circumstances.

name: texas
sentence: Note the 2004 Christmas Eve snowstorm, where 6 inches (150 mm) of snow fell as far south as Kingsville, where the average temperature was 65°F in December.

name: texas
sentence: Maximum summer temperatures are on average 80°F (26°C) in the mountains of western Texas and Galveston Island at approximately 100°F (38°C) in the Rio Grande Valley, but most regions of Texas see constant high summer temperatures in the 90°F (32°C) range.

name: texas
sentence: Morning temperatures at night are from 50 °F (14 °C) in the western Texas mountains to 80 °F (27 °C) in Galveston.

name: texas
sentence: The table below consists of averages for August (usually the warmest month) and January (usually the coldest) in some cities in different regions of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Thunderstorms often hit Texas, especially the eastern and northern parts of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Tornado Alley covers the northern part of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The state is experiencing the most tornadoes in the United States, with an average of 139 tornadoes per year.

name: texas
sentence: These strikes are the most common in northern Texas and the Panhandle.

name: texas
sentence: tornadoes usually occur in Texas during the months of April, May and June.

name: texas
sentence: Some of the most destructive hurricanes in American history have hit Texas.

name: texas
sentence: A hurricane of 1875 killed about 400 people in Indianola, followed by another hurricane of 1886 that destroyed the city.

name: texas
sentence: These events enabled Galveston to take over as the main port city.

name: texas
sentence: Hurricane Galveston of 1900 then devastated this city, killing about 8,000 people, and even up to 12,000 people.

name: texas
sentence: This makes it the most deadly natural disaster in the history of the United States.

name: texas
sentence: In 2017, Hurricane Harvey fell in Rockport as a Category 4 hurricane, causing significant damage.

name: texas
sentence: The storm lasted a long time, allowing it to drop unprecedented amounts of rain on the Greater Houston area and surrounding counties.

name: texas
sentence: The result has been widespread and catastrophic floods that have flooded hundreds of thousands of homes.

name: texas
sentence: Harvey eventually became the most expensive hurricane in the world, causing damage estimated at $198.6 billion, exceeding the cost of Hurricane Katrina.

name: texas
sentence: Other devastating hurricanes in Texas include Hurricane Galveston of 1915, Hurricane Audrey in 1957, which killed more than 600 people, Hurricane Carla in 1961, Hurricane Beula in 1967, Hurricane Alicia in 1983, Hurricane Rita in 2005 and Hurricane Ike in 2008.

name: texas
sentence: Tropical storms also caused their share of damage: Allison in 1989 and again in 2001, and Claudette in 1979.

name: texas
sentence: In 2017, Texas emits the most greenhouse gases in the U.S. nearly twice as much as California, the second most polluting state.In 2017, the state emits about 1,600 billion pounds (707 million metric tons) of carbon dioxide per year.

name: texas
sentence: As an independent nation, Texas would be the world's seventh largest producer of greenhouse gases.

name: texas
sentence: The causes of the government's large greenhouse gas emissions include the large number of coal-fired power plants and the government's refining and manufacturing industries.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, there were 2,553 "emission events" that contributed 44.6 million pounds (20,200 metric tonnes) of contaminants to the Texas sky.

name: texas
sentence: The State has three cities with more than one million inhabitants: Houston, San Antonio and Dallas.

name: texas
sentence: These three cities are among the 10 most populated cities in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, six cities in Texas had more than 600,000 inhabitants.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Fort Worth and El Paso are among the 20 largest cities in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has four metropolitan areas with more than one million inhabitants: Dallas–Fort Worth–Arlington, Houston–Sugar Land–The Woodlands, San Antonio–New Braunfels and Austin–Round Rock–San Marcos.

name: texas
sentence: The metropolitan areas of Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston have approximately 7.5 million and 7 million residents respectively in 2019.

name: texas
sentence: Three interstate highways – I-35 to the west (Dallas–Fort Worth in San Antonio, with Austin in between), I-45 to the east (Dallas in Houston), and I-10 to the south (San Antonio in Houston) define the region of the Texas urban triangle.

name: texas
sentence: The 160,000-square-kilometre (160,000 km2) area is home to most of the largest cities and metropolitan areas of the state, as well as 17 million people, representing almost 75 per cent of the total population of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Houston and Dallas have been recognized as cities of the world.

name: texas
sentence: These cities are distributed throughout the State.

name: texas
sentence: Unlike cities, unincorporated rural settlements, called colonias, often lack basic infrastructure and are marked by poverty.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Attorney General's Office reported in 2011 that Texas had approximately 2,294 colonias and estimated that about 500,000 people lived in the colonies.

name: texas
sentence: Hidalgo County, in 2011, has the largest number of colonias.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the largest number of people in all states, living in settlements.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 254 counties, more than any other state by 95 (Georgia).

name: texas
sentence: Each county has a judicial system composed of four elected commissioners (one of each of the four county precincts, divided roughly according to population) and one county judge elected throughout the county.

name: texas
sentence: The county government is similar to a "low" mayor-counsel system; the county judge has no veto authority, but votes with the other commissioners.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas allows cities and counties to enter into "interlocal agreements" to share services, the state does not allow consolidated city and county governments, nor metropolitan governments.

name: texas
sentence: Counties do not have ownership status.

name: texas
sentence: The State has no cantons — the regions of a county are incorporated or not.

name: texas
sentence: The incorporated areas are part of a municipality.

name: texas
sentence: The county provides services limited to unincorporated areas and some smaller incorporated areas.

name: texas
sentence: Municipalities are classified as "general law" or "rule of residence".

name: texas
sentence: A municipality may choose the status of owner as soon as it exceeds 5,000 inhabitants with the approval of the elector.

name: texas
sentence: Texas also allows for the creation of "special districts", which offer limited services.

name: texas
sentence: The most common is the school district, but may also include hospital districts, community colleges districts and public services districts (a public services district near Austin was the plaintiff in a landmark Supreme Court case concerning the Voting Rights Act).

name: texas
sentence: Municipal elections, school districts and special electoral districts are non-partisan, although the affiliation of a candidate to a party may be well known.

name: texas
sentence: The county and state elections are partisan.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, Texas had 25,145,561 inhabitants.

name: texas
sentence: The United States Census Office estimated that the population of Texas was 29,360,759 on 1 July 2020, an increase of 16.76 per cent over the 2010 United States Census.

name: texas
sentence: According to the Texas 2015 population estimation program, the population was 27,469,114 on July 1, 2015.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is the second most populous state in the United States after California.

name: texas
sentence: In 2015, Texas had 4.7 million foreign-born residents, approximately 17% of the population and 21.6% of the state's workforce.

sentence: Mexico (55.0 per cent of immigrants), India (5 per cent), El Salvador (4.3 per cent), Vietnam (3.7 per cent) and China (2.3 per cent) were the main countries of origin.

sentence: About 35.8% of immigrants were naturalized American citizens.

sentence: In 2018, the population increased from 2,899,642 in 2000 to 4.9 million foreign-born residents, representing 17.2% of the state's population.

sentence: In addition to the foreign-born population of the state, an additional 4.1 million Texans (15 per cent of the state population) were born in the United States and have at least one immigrant parent.

name: texas
sentence: Of the undocumented immigrants, 960,000 resided in Texas between the ages of 5 and 14.

sentence: It is estimated that 637,000 people lived in Texas between the ages of 15 and 19 years and older.

sentence: The Texas Rio Grande Valley has experienced significant migration across the border between the United States and Mexico.

name: texas

name: texas
sentence: Many have applied for asylum in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's population density is 90.5 people per square mile (34.9/km2), which is slightly higher than the average population density of the United States as a whole, at 80.6 people per square mile (31.1/km2).

name: texas
sentence: On the other hand, while Texas and France have a similar geographical size, the European country has a population density of 301.8 people per square mile (116.5/km2).

sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area is the largest in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In 2015, non-Hispanic whites accounted for 11,505,371 (41.9%) of the population, followed by Black Americans at 3,171,043 (11.5%); other races at 1,793,580 (6.5%); and Hispanics and Latinos (of all races) at 10,999,120 (40.0%).

name: texas
sentence: According to the 2010 census of the United States, the racial composition of Texas was as follows: American white 70.4 per cent, (non-Hispanic whites 45.3 per cent), Black or Afro-American 11.8 per cent, American Indian 0.7 per cent, Asian 3.8 per cent (1.0 per cent Indian, 0.8 per cent Vietnamese, 0.6 per cent Chinese, 0.4 per cent Filipino, 0.3 per cent Korean, 0.1 per cent Japanese, 0.6 per cent Other Asian), Pacific Island 0.1 per cent, another 10.5 per cent and two or more races 2.7 per cent.

sentence: In 2011, 69.8% of Texas's population under 1 years of age were minorities (i.e., they had at least one non-Hispanic white parent).

name: texas
sentence: In 1980, the Germans, Irish and American English made the three largest groups of European ancestry in Texas.

sentence: American Germans make up 11.3% of the population and have more than 2.7 million members.

name: texas
sentence: There are approximately 600,000 American French, 472,000 American Italians, 369,161 American Scots and 288,610 American Poles residing in Texas; these four ethnic groups account for 2.5 per cent, 2.0 per cent, 1.5 per cent and 1.0 per cent of the population, respectively.

sentence: In the 1980 U.S. Census, the largest ancestry group reported in Texas was English, with 3,083,323 Texans citing their English or predominantly English ancestry, making it 27 percent of the state at the time.

sentence: Larger in Texas by size and passengers served, the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) is the second largest by region in the United States, and the fourth largest in the world with 18,076 acres (73.15 km2).

sentence: In traffic, DFW's airport is the busiest in the state, the fourth busiest in the United States, and the sixth busiest in the world.

name: texas
sentence: American Airlines Group, the largest airline in the world in terms of passenger miles and passenger fleet size, uses DFW as its largest and largest hub.

name: texas
sentence: It ranks as the largest airline in the United States by the number of passengers transported to the country per year and the largest airline in the world by the number of passengers transported.Southwest Airlines, headquartered in Dallas, operates in Dallas Love Field.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's second largest air facility is Houston Intercontinental George Bush Airport (IAH).

name: texas
sentence: It served as the largest hub for the former Continental Airlines, which was based in Houston; it is the largest hub for United Airlines, the third largest airline in the world, per passenger mile.

name: texas
sentence: IAH offers a service to the most Mexican destinations of any American airport.

name: texas
sentence: The other five largest airports in the state serve more than three million passengers each year, including Austin-Bergstrom International Airport, William P. Hobby Airport, San Antonio International Airport, Dallas Love Field and El Paso International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The smallest airport in the state to be designated as an international airport is Del Rio International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: Approximately 1,150 seaports provide the Texas coast with more than 1,600 km of canals.

name: texas
sentence: Ports employ nearly one million people and handle an average of 317 million tonnes.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ports connect to the rest of the Atlantic coast of the United States with the Gulf section of the Intracoastal Waterway.

name: texas
sentence: The port of Houston is now the busiest port in the United States in foreign tonnage, the second in total tonnage and the tenth in the world in tonnage.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Canal extends 160 metres wide by 22 metres deep and 80 kilometres long.

name: texas
sentence: Part of the state's cowboy tradition is derived from the large cattle roads that its herders organized in the 19th century to drive cattle to the railways and markets of Kansas, for the expedition to the East.

name: texas
sentence: Cities along the way, such as Baxter Springs, Kansas' first cow town, have developed to care for seasonal workers and tens of thousands of cattle.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to operate in Texas was the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway, which opened in August 1853.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to enter Texas from the north, completed in 1872, was the Missouri–Kansas–Texas Railway.

name: texas
sentence: With increased access to the railway, farmers did not have to take their cattle to the Midwest and shipped beef from Texas.

name: texas
sentence: This has led to a decline in the economy of cow towns.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1911, Texas has led the nation over miles of railway within the state.

name: texas
sentence: The length of the Texas Railway peaked in 1932 at 17,078 miles (27,484 kilometres), but decreased to 14,006 miles (35,540 kilometres) in 2000.

name: texas
sentence: While the Texas Railway Commission initially regulated the state railways, in 2005 the state reallocated these rights to TxDOT.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas–Fort Worth area, three public transit organizations provide rail service: Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA) and Trinity Metro.

name: texas
sentence: DART began operating the first light rail system in the southwestern United States in 1996.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Railway Express (TRE), a suburban rail service linking Fort Worth and Dallas, is provided by Trinity Metro and DART.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Metro also operates the TEXRail suburban railway line, connecting downtown Fort Worth and Northeast Tarrant County to DFW Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The commuter A train line operated by DCTA serves as an extension of the DART Green line in Denton County.

name: texas
sentence: In the Austin area, the Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority operates a suburban rail service called Capital MetroRail to the northwest suburbs.

name: texas
sentence: The Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas (METRO) operates light rail lines in the Houston area.

name: texas
sentence: Amtrak provides Texas with a limited long distance rail service.

name: texas
sentence: Three regular itineraries serve the state: Texas Eagle (Chicago–San Antonio), Sunset Limited (New Orleans–Los Angeles), with stops in Texas, and Heartland Flyer (Fort Worth–Oklahoma City).

name: texas
sentence: Texas could have one of the country's first high-speed lines.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Central Railway Company has planned the construction of a privately funded high-speed railway line between Dallas and Houston.

name: texas
sentence: The current Texas Constitution was adopted in 1876.

name: texas
sentence: Like many States, it explicitly provides for a separation of powers.

name: texas
sentence: The State Bill of Rights is much larger than its federal bill of rights and contains Texas-specific provisions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive branch limiting the power of the governor, which is a weak executive in comparison to other states.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of the Secretary of State, electors elect the leaders independently, so candidates are directly accountable to the public, not to the Governor.

name: texas
sentence: This electoral system has led to the division of certain executive powers among the parties and has reduced the governor's ability to carry out a programme.

name: texas
sentence: When Republican President George W. Bush was governor of Texas, the state had a democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

name: texas
sentence: The Executive is composed of the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Land Commissioner, the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Agriculture, the Texas Railway Commission, the State Council of Education and the Secretary of State.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's bicameral Parliament consists of the House of Representatives, with 150 members, and one senator, with 31 members.

name: texas
sentence: The Speaker of the House presides over the House, and the Lieutenant Governor, the Senator.

name: texas
sentence: The legislature meets in ordinary session every two years for just over a hundred days, but the governor may request special sessions as often as desired (notably, the legislature cannot meet itself).

name: texas
sentence: The fiscal year of the State begins on 1 September.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's judiciary is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two courts of last resort: the Texas Supreme Court, for civil cases, and the Texas Criminal Court of Appeal.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of some municipal benches, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the governor fills vacancies by appointment.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is remarkable for its use of capital punishment, having led the country to executions since the death penalty was reinstated in Gregg v. Georgia (see capital punishment in Texas).

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety is a law enforcement agency within the jurisdiction of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Over the years, the Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption.

name: texas
sentence: They acted as riot police and inspectors, protected the governor of Texas, hunted fugitives and acted as a paramilitary force both for the republic and for the state.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Rangers were created informally by Stephen F. Austin in 1823 and officially formed in 1835.

name: texas
sentence: The Rangers were an integral part of several important events in Texas's history and some of the most well-known criminal cases in Old West history.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments, which serve as agents of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The so-called Commissioners, the judges of the courts, are elected to serve as an administrative body.

name: texas
sentence: Most of the state's cities, with more than 5,000 inhabitants, have autonomous governments.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of them have charters for forms of council-managerial government, by which voters elect members of the council, who hire a director of a professional town as an operating officer.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1870s, the White Democrats regained power in the state legislature of the biracial coalition at the end of the reconstruction.

name: texas
sentence: At the beginning of the 20th century, Parliament passed bills to impose voting taxes, followed by white primaries; these measures effectively deprived most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1890s, 100,000 Blacks voted in the state; in 1906, only 5,000 could vote.

name: texas
sentence: As a result, the Democratic Party dominated Texas politics at the beginning of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy.

name: texas
sentence: It exercised power until the adoption in the mid-1960s of national legislation on civil rights that respected the constitutional rights of all citizens.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas was essentially a single-party state during this period and democratic primary was considered "the real election", the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the New Deal.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, several factions of the party separated briefly in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: texas
sentence: Conservative white voters in the state began supporting Republican presidential candidates in the middle of the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: After this period, they also supported Republicans for local and state offices, and most whites became members of the Republican Party.

name: texas
sentence: The party also attracted some minorities, but many continued to vote for democratic candidates.

name: texas
sentence: The passage to the Republican Party is largely attributed to the fact that the Democratic Party became increasingly liberal during the 20th century, and thus increasingly uncontrollable with the average voter in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: As Texas has always been a conservative state, voters have turned to the GOP, which now more closely reflects their beliefs.

name: texas
sentence: Commentators also attributed this change to Republican political consultant Karl Rove, who managed many political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.

name: texas
sentence: Other reasons cited include the redistribution ordered by the court and the demographic change in relation to the Sun Belt that favored the Republican Party and conservatism.

name: texas
sentence: The reconfiguration of Congressional districts led by Republican Tom DeLay in 2003 in Texas was called by the New York Times "an extreme case of partisan Gerrymandering".

name: texas
sentence: A group of democratic legislators, the "Texas Eleven", fled the state in an attempt to abuse quorum to prevent the legislator from acting, but failed.

name: texas
sentence: The State had already redesigned as a result of the 2000 census.

name: texas
sentence: Despite these efforts, the legislator has adopted a map strongly in favour of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimates of nearly a million new residents in the state since then.

name: texas
sentence: Career lawyers and analysts in the Department of Justice opposed this plan by diluting the votes of African-American and Hispanic voters, but the political appointees stole and approved it.

name: texas
sentence: In League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry (2006), the National Supreme Court received an appeal for review, but the Court ruled in favour of the State (and Republicans).

name: texas
sentence: In the 2014 Texas election, the Tea Party movement made great progress, with many of the Tea Party's favourites elected to power, including Dan Patrick as Lieutenant Governor, Ken Paxton as Attorney General, as well as many other candidates including Conservative Republican Greg Abbott as Governor.

name: texas
sentence: Electors in Texas are leaning towards fiscal conservatism, while taking advantage of the enormous federal investments in the state in military and other facilities obtained by the power of the South Solid in the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: They also tend to have socially conservative values.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, most voters in Texas have supported candidates for the Republican presidency.

name: texas
sentence: In 2000 and 2004, Republican George W. Bush won Texas with 59.3 percent and 60.1 percent respectively, partly because of his status as "preferential son" as former state governor.

name: texas
sentence: John McCain won the state in 2008, but with a lower margin of victory than Bush at 55 percent of the vote.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio are constantly focusing on democracy in local and state-wide elections.

name: texas
sentence: The demographic evolution of the state can lead to a change in its overall political alignment, as a majority population of black and Hispanic/Latino voters supports the Democratic Party.

name: texas
sentence: Residents of counties along the Rio Grande, closer to the Mexico-United States border, where there are many Latin American residents, generally vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas voted for Republican Party candidates.

name: texas
sentence: As of the 2014 general election, a large majority of the delegation of the U.S. House of Texas are Republicans, as well as the two United States.

name: texas
sentence: Senators.

name: texas
sentence: At the 114th Congress of the United States of America, of the 36 Congress districts in Texas, 24 are held by Republicans and 11 by Democrats.

name: texas
sentence: One seat is vacant.

name: texas
sentence: The senators from Texas are John Cornyn and Ted Cruz.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1994, the Texans have not elected a democrat to a state-wide position.

name: texas
sentence: The state's democratic voters are mainly Liberal and minority groups in Austin, Beaumont, Dallas, El Paso, Houston and San Antonio, as well as minority voters in eastern and southern Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas banned the sanctuary cities, but the mayor of Houston Sylvester Turner promised that the city would not help ICE agents.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a reputation for very severe criminal punishment for criminal offences.

name: texas
sentence: It is one of the 32 states that use capital punishment, and since the Supreme Court of the United States allowed the resumption of capital punishment in 1976, 40 per cent of all United States executions have taken place in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In 2008, Texas had the fourth highest incarceration rate in the United States, and it also has self-defence laws that allow citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families or their property.

name: texas
sentence: While American football has long been considered a "king" in the state, Texans enjoy a wide variety of sports.

name: texas
sentence: Texans can encourage a plethora of professional sports teams.

name: texas
sentence: Within the four major professional leagues, Texas has two NFL teams (the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Texans), two major league baseball teams (the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers), three NBA teams (the San Antonio Spurs, the Houston Rockets and the Dallas Mavericks) and one National Hockey League team (the Dallas Stars).

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth Metroplex is one of twelve metropolitan areas in the United States that host sports teams from all professional leagues of the Big Four.

name: texas
sentence: Apart from the Big Four, Texas also has a WNBA team (the Dallas Wings) and two teams from the Major Football League (the Houston Dynamo and FC Dallas).

name: texas
sentence: College athletics has a profound significance in Texas culture, especially football.

name: texas
sentence: The State has 12 schools in the I-FBS Division, the most populated in the country.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's universities, Baylor Bears, Texas Longhorns, TCU Horned Frogs and Texas Tech Red Raiders, participate in the Great 12 Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Texas A&M Aggies left the Big 12 and joined the South East Conference in 2012, which led the Big 12 to invite the TCU to join; TCU was previously at the Mountain West Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Cougars and Mustangs of the SMU participate in the American athletic conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Bobcats of the State of Texas and the UT Arlington Mavericks participate in the Sun Belt conference.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's schools claim at least one national football championship: Texas Longhorns, Texas A&M Agies, TCU Horned Frogs, and SMU Mustangs.

name: texas
sentence: According to an investigation by the I-A Division, rivalry between Oklahoma University and the University of Texas at Austin, the Red River Shootout, ranks third in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: TCU's horned frogs and Mustangs SMU also share a rivalry and participate each year in the battle for the Iron Skullet.

name: texas
sentence: A fierce rivalry, the Lone Star Showdown, also exists between the two largest universities in the state, Texas A&M University and the University of Texas at Austin.

name: texas
sentence: The athletic part of the Lone Star Showdown rivalry was suspended after the Texas Aggies joined the Southeast Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The University Interscholastic League (UIL) organizes most of the competitions in primary and secondary schools.

name: texas
sentence: The events organized by UIL include athletics competitions (the most popular being secondary football) as well as artistic and academic disciplines.

name: texas
sentence: Texans also like rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: The first rodeo in the world was hosted in Pecos, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The annual Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo is the largest rodeo in the world.

name: texas
sentence: It begins with hikes from several points of the state that meet in Reliant Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Southwest Exhibition and Livestock Show at Fort Worth is the oldest continuous rodeo incorporating several of the most historic traditions of the state in its annual events.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas hosts the Texas State Fair in Fair Park every year.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1997, Texas Motor Speedway has hosted annual races from the NASCAR Cup Series and the IndyCar Series.

name: texas
sentence: Since 2012, Austin's Circuit of the Americas has hosted a Formula 1 World Championship round – the first on a permanent road circuit in the United States since the 1980 Grand Prix at Watkins Glen International – as well as Grand Prix motorcycle races, FIA World Endurance Championship and United SportsCar Championship.

name: utah
sentence: Utah (YOO-tah) is a state in the western United States of America.

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south, and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico in the southeast.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty American states, Utah is the 13th largest by region; with a population of more than three million, it is the 30th most populated and the 11th least dense.

name: utah
sentence: Urban development is concentrated mainly in two regions: the Wasatch Front, in the north-central part of the state, which is home to about two thirds of the population and includes the capital, Salt Lake City, and Washington County, in the south, with more than 170,000 inhabitants.

name: utah
sentence: Most of western Utah lies in the Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: The territory of modern Utah has been inhabited by various Aboriginal groups for thousands of years, including the former Pueblans, Navajo and Ute.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards were the first Europeans to arrive in the mid-16th century, although the region's difficult geography and climate made it a peripheral part of New Spain and later Mexico.

name: utah
sentence: Although part of Mexico, many of the first settlers in Utah were American, especially Mormons fleeing the marginalization and persecution of the United States.

name: utah
sentence: After the war between Mexico and the United States, it is part of the territory of Utah, which includes what is now Colorado and Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Disputes between the dominant Mormon community and the federal government delayed the admission of Utah as a state; it was only after the prohibition of polygamy that it was admitted as 45th in 1896.

name: utah
sentence: Just over half of all Utahns are Mormons, the vast majority of whom are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Last-Day Saints (LDS Church), which has its global headquarters in Salt Lake City.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where the majority of the population belongs to a single church.

name: utah
sentence: The LDS Church greatly influences Uthah's culture, politics and daily life, although, since the 1990s, the state has become more religiously and secularly diverse.

name: utah
sentence: The State has a very diverse economy, with important sectors such as transportation, education, information technology and research, government services, mining, and an important tourist destination for outdoor recreation.

name: utah
sentence: In 2013, the U.S. Census Bureau estimated that Utah had the fastest population in any state.

name: utah
sentence: St. George was the fastest growing metropolitan area in the United States between 2000 and 2005.

name: utah
sentence: Utah also has the highest average income and the lowest income inequality of all U.S. states.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 Gallup national survey revealed that Utah was generally the "best state to live in the future" based on 13 forward-looking measures, including various measures of economic prospects, lifestyle and health.

name: utah
sentence: It is said that the name Utah derives from the name of the tribe Ute, which means "people of the mountains."

name: utah
sentence: However, no such word actually exists in the language of the Utes, and the Utes refer to themselves as Noochee.

name: utah
sentence: The meaning of Utes as "the mountain people" has been attributed to neighbouring Pueblo Indians, as well as to the word Apache Yuttahih, which means "the one who is higher" or "the ones who are higher".

name: utah
sentence: In Spanish, Yuta was pronounced

name: utah
sentence: Thousands of years before the arrival of European explorers, the Pueblons Ancestral and the Fremont people lived in what is now called Utah, some of which spoke the languages of the Uto-Aztecan group.

name: utah
sentence: The peoples of ancient Pueblo built their houses by excavations in the mountains, and the people of Fremont built straw houses before disappearing from the area around the 15th century.

name: utah
sentence: Another group of Amerindians, Navajo, settled in the area around the 18th century.

name: utah
sentence: In the middle of the 18th century, other Uto-Aztecan tribes, including the Goshute, the Paiute, the Shoshone and the Ute people, also settled in the area.

name: utah
sentence: These five groups were present when the first European explorers arrived.

name: utah
sentence: The southern region of Utah was explored by the Spaniards in 1540, led by Francisco Vázquez de Coronado, while searching for the legendary Cíbola.

name: utah
sentence: A group led by two Catholic priests – sometimes called the Domínguez-Escalante expedition – left Santa Fe in 1776, hoping to find a road to the Californian coast.

name: utah
sentence: The expedition travelled as far north as Lake Utah and met with Aboriginal residents.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards made further explorations in the region but were not interested in colonizing the region because of its desert nature.

name: utah
sentence: In 1821, when Mexico gained independence from Spain, the region became known as part of its Alta California territory.

name: utah
sentence: In the early 19th century, European trappers and fur traders explored parts of Utah in Canada and the United States.

name: utah
sentence: The town of Provo, Utah, was named in honour of Étienne Provost, who visited the area in 1825.

name: utah
sentence: The town of Ogden, Utah, is named after Peter Skene Ogden, a Canadian explorer who sells furs in the Weber Valley.

name: utah
sentence: At the end of 1824, Jim Bridger became the first known English speaker to visit Great Salt Lake.

name: utah
sentence: Because of the high salinity of his waters, he thought he had found the Pacific Ocean; he later learned that this body of water was a giant salt lake.

name: utah
sentence: After the discovery of the lake, hundreds of American and Canadian traders and trappers established trading posts in the area.

name: utah
sentence: In the 1830s, thousands of migrants travelling from the eastern United States to the western United States began making stops in the area of Great Salt Lake, then known as Lake Youta.

name: utah
sentence: After Joseph Smith's death in 1844, Brigham Young, as president of the Quorum of Twelve, became the effective leader of the LDS Church in Nauvoo, Illinois.

name: utah
sentence: To resolve the growing conflicts between his people and his neighbours, Young agreed with Illinois Governor Thomas Ford in October 1845 that the Mormons would leave by the following year.

name: utah
sentence: Young and the first band of Mormon pioneers reached the Salt Lake valley on July 24, 1847.

name: utah
sentence: Over the next 22 years, more than 70,000 pioneers crossed the plains and settled in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: In the early years, Brigham Young and the thousands of first settlers in Salt Lake City struggled to survive.

name: utah
sentence: The arid desert land was judged by the Mormons as desirable as a place where they could practice their religion without harassment.

name: utah
sentence: The settlers buried thirty-six Amerindians in a grave after an outbreak of measles in the winter of 1847.

name: utah
sentence: The first group of settlers brought African slaves with them, making Utah the only place in the western United States where African slavery.

name: utah
sentence: Three slaves, Green Flake, Hark Lay and Oscar Crosby, came west with the first group of settlers in 1847.

name: utah
sentence: Settlers also began to buy Indian slaves in the established Indian slave trade, as well as Indian prisoners of war enslaved.

name: utah
sentence: Utah was a Mexican territory when the first pioneers arrived in 1847.

name: utah
sentence: By the beginning of the war between Mexico and America, at the end of 1846, the United States had taken control of New Mexico and California.

name: utah
sentence: The whole Southwest became American territory when the treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was signed on 2 February 1848.

name: utah
sentence: The treaty was ratified by the United States Senator on March 11.

name: utah
sentence: Upon learning that California and New Mexico were applying for state status, settlers in the Utah region (which had originally planned to apply for territory status) submitted a state status application with an ambitious plan for a State of Desert.

name: utah
sentence: The Mormon colonies were pioneers for other western colonies.

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City has become the centre of a "distant community" of the Mormon colonies.

name: utah
sentence: With new conversions of churches from the East and from all over the world, church leaders have often assigned groups of church members as missionaries to establish other settlements throughout the West.

name: utah
sentence: They developed irrigation to support relatively large pioneer populations along the Utah Wasatch Front (Salt Lake City, Bountiful and Weber Valley, and Provo and Utah Valley).

name: utah
sentence: Throughout the 19th century, Mormon pioneers established hundreds of other settlements in Utah, Idaho, Nevada, Arizona, Wyoming, California, Canada and Mexico, including Las Vegas, Nevada, Franklin, Idaho (first European colony in Idaho), San Bernardino, California, Mesa, Arizona, Star Valley, Wyoming and Carson Valley, Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Among the most important settlements in Utah are St. George, Logan and Manti (where the settlers completed the first three Utah temples, each having started after but completed several years before the larger and better-known Salt Lake City temple was completed in 1893), as well as Parowan, Cedar City, Bluff, Moab, Vernal, Fillmore (which served as the territorial capital between 1850 and 1856), Nephi, Levan, Spanish Fork, Springville, Provo Bench (now Orem), Pleasant Grove, American Fork, Lehi, Sandy, Murray, Jordan, Centerville, Farmington, Huntsville, Kaysville, Grantsville, Tooele, Roy, Brigham City and many other smaller cities and settlements.

name: utah
sentence: Young had an expansionist view of the territory that he was settling with Mormon pioneers, calling Deseret, who, according to the Book of Mormon, was an ancient word for "the domestic bee".

name: utah
sentence: This is symbolized by the hive on the flag of Utah, and the motto of the state, "Industry".

name: utah
sentence: The territory of Utah was much smaller than the proposed state of Desert, but it still contained all the present states of Nevada and Utah as well as modern Wyoming and Colorado pieces.

name: utah
sentence: It was created with the 1850 compromise, and Fillmore, named after President Millard Fillmore, was named the capital.

name: utah
sentence: The territory was named Utah after the Ute tribe of the Amerindians.

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City replaced Fillmore as the territorial capital in 1856.

name: utah
sentence: In 1850, there were a hundred Blacks on the territory, the majority of whom were slaves.

name: utah
sentence: In Salt Lake County, 26 slaves were counted.

name: utah
sentence: In 1852, the Territory's legislature passed the Service Act and the Act on Assistance to Slaves and Indian Prisoners who officially legalize slavery in the Territory.

name: utah
sentence: Slavery was abolished in the territory during the civil war.

name: utah
sentence: In 1850 Salt Lake City sent a force called the Nauvoo Legion and engaged the Timpanogos in the battle at Fort Utah.

name: utah
sentence: The differences between the Mormon inhabitants and the American government have intensified as a result of the practice of plural, or polygamy, marriage between the members of the Church of Jesus Christ of the Saints of the last days.

name: utah
sentence: The Mormons continue to press for the establishment of a State of Desert with the new borders of the territory of Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Most, if not all, members of the U.S. government opposed the Mormon polygamous practices.

name: utah
sentence: Members of the LDS Church were considered non-American and rebel when news of their polygamous practices spread.

name: utah
sentence: In 1857, particularly heinous accusations of government abdication and general immorality were raised by former associate judge William W. Drummond, among others.

name: utah
sentence: Detailed reports on life in Utah caused the administration of James Buchanan to send a secret military "expedition" to Utah.

name: utah
sentence: When the so-called rebellion was to be repressed, Alfred Cumming would take the place of Brigham Young as territorial governor.

name: utah
sentence: The resulting conflict is known as the Utah War, nicknamed "Buchanan's Blunder" by Mormon leaders.

name: utah
sentence: In September 1857, about 120 American settlers of the Baker-Fancher ferry train, en route to California from Arkansas, were murdered by the territorial militia of Utah and some Paiute Indians in the Mountain Meadows massacre.

name: utah
sentence: Before the troops led by Albert Sidney Johnston entered the territory, Brigham Young ordered all residents of Salt Lake City to evacuate south to the Utah Valley and sent the Nauvoo Legion to delay the government's advance.

name: utah
sentence: Although cars and supplies were burned, the troops arrived in 1858, and Young transferred official control to Cumming, although most of the subsequent commentators claimed that Young retained real power in the territory.

name: utah
sentence: A constant flow of governors appointed by the President left the post, often citing the traditions of their so-called territorial government.

name: utah
sentence: In agreement with Young, Johnston established Camp Floyd, 60 km from Salt Lake City, southwest.

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City was the last link of the first transcontinental telegraph, completed in October 1861.

name: utah
sentence: Brigham Young was among the first to send a message, along with Abraham Lincoln and other officials.

name: utah
sentence: As a result of the American civil war, federal troops were withdrawn from Utah territory in 1861.

name: utah
sentence: It was an advantage for the local economy because the army sold everything in the camp for cents on the dollar before walking east to join the war.

name: utah

sentence: Utah is known for its natural diversity and has features ranging from arid deserts with sand dunes to prosperous pine forests in mountain valleys.

sentence: One of the defining features of Utah is the variety of its terrain.

name: utah
sentence: One of the most impressive but least visited attractions in western Utah is Notch Peak, the highest limestone cliff in North America, located west of Delta.

sentence: Much of the picturesque landscape of the south and south-east (especially the Colorado Plateau region) is sandstone, particularly Kayenta sandstone and Navajo sandstone.

sentence: Like most western and southwestern states, the federal government owns much of Utah's land.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where each county contains a national forest.

name: utah
sentence: Utah has a dry, semi-arid climate in the desert, although its many mountains have a wide variety of climates, the highest points in the mountains of Uinta being above the wood line.

name: utah
sentence: Dry weather is the result of the state's location in the rain shadow of Sierra Nevada, California.

name: utah
sentence: Half of the eastern state lies in the rain shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: The main source of precipitation for the state is the Pacific Ocean, with the state usually on the way to major Pacific storms from October to May.

name: utah
sentence: In summer, the state, especially the south and east of Utah, is on the path to monsoon moisture from the Gulf of California.

name: utah
sentence: Most lowlands receive less than 12 inches (305 mm) of precipitation per year, although corridor I-15, including the densely populated Wasatch Front, receives about 15 inches (381 mm).

name: utah
sentence: The Great Salt Lake Desert is the driest area in the state, with less than 5 inches (127 mm).

name: utah
sentence: Snowfall is common in all valleys, with the exception of southern valleys.

sentence: Although St. George receives only about 3 inches (76 mm) per year, Salt Lake City sees about 60 inches (1,524 mm), increased by snow from the Great Salt Lake effect, increasing total snowfall to the south, south-east and east of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: Some areas of the Wasatch range in the lake effect trail receive up to 500 inches (12,700 mm) per year.

name: utah
sentence: This micro-climate of increased snowfall from Great Salt Lake extends throughout the vicinity of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The cotton canyons adjacent to Salt Lake City are located in the right position to receive more precipitation from the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The ever-deep powder snow has led the Utah ski industry to adopt the slogan "The greatest snow on earth" in the 1980s.

name: utah
sentence: In winter, temperature inversions are a common phenomenon in Utah basins and valleys, resulting in thick fog and fog that can last weeks at a time, especially in the Uintah basin.

name: utah
sentence: Although at other times of the year its air quality is good, winter inversions give Salt Lake City one of the worst winter pollution in the country.

name: utah
sentence: Previous studies have shown a widespread decline in snow quantity on Utah, accompanied by a decline in snow-precipitation ratio, while anecdotal claims have been made that the measured changes in snow quantity in Utah are false and do not reflect actual changes.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 study found that the proportion of winter precipitation (January to March) falling as snow has decreased by 9% over the last half century, a combined result of a significant increase in precipitation and a slight decrease in snowfall.

sentence: During this time, snow depth observed in Utah decreased and was accompanied by a steady decrease in snow cover and surface albedo.

name: utah
sentence: Weather systems likely to produce precipitation in Utah have decreased in number, with those that produce snowfall decreasing at a much higher rate.

name: utah
sentence: Utah's temperatures are extreme, with cold temperatures in winter due to its rise, and very hot summers on a state scale (except for mountain areas and high mountain valleys).

sentence: Utah is usually protected from major cold air explosions by mountains to the north and east of the state, although major Arctic explosions may sometimes reach the state.

sentence: Mean high January temperatures range from about 30°F (−1°C) in some northern valleys to nearly 55°F (13°C) in St. George.

sentence: Temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) are expected occasionally in most regions of the state in most years, although some regions often see it (for example, the city of Randolph has an average of about fifty days a year with such low temperatures).

sentence: In July, average heights range from about 85 to 100°F (29 to 38°C).

name: utah
sentence: Utah, like most of the Western United States, has a few days of thunderstorms.

sentence: On average, there are less than 40 days of stormy activity during the year, although these storms may be briefly intense when they occur.

name: utah
sentence: They are more likely to occur during the monsoon season, from mid-July to mid-September, particularly in southern and eastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Dry lightning strikes and the general dry weather often triggers forest fires in summer, while intense thunderstorms can cause flash floods, especially in the rugged southern Utah terrain.

name: utah
sentence: Although spring is the wettest season in northern Utah, late summer is the wettest time for much of southern and eastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: tornadoes are uncommon in Utah, with an average of two striking the state each year, rarely more intense than the EF1.

sentence: An exception, however, was the unprecedented F2 Salt Lake City Tornado that moved directly to downtown Salt Lake City on August 11, 1999, killing one person, wounding another sixty, and causing approximately $170 million in damage.

name: virginia
sentence: In 2017, agriculture occupied 28 percent of Virginia's land with 7.8 million acres (12,188 m2; 31,565 km2) of agricultural land.

sentence: Virginia collects personal income tax from those with income above a reporting threshold; there are five income brackets, ranging from 2.0% to 5.75 percent of taxable income.

sentence: Virginia has a mixed health status, and has been ranked as the 15th healthyest overall health status according to the 2019 health rankings of the United Health Foundation.

sentence: As a result of the Byrd Road Act of 1932, the state government controlled most of Virginia's roads, rather than a local county administration, as in other states.

sentence: In 2018, the Virginia Department of Transportation owns and operates 57,867 miles (93,128 km) of the 70,105 miles (112,823 km) of state roads, making it the third-largest state road network in the United States.

name: virginia
sentence: In 1619, the first General Assembly of Virginia met at Jamestown Church and had 22 local elected representatives, making Virginia's legislature the oldest in North America.

name: virginia
sentence: These representatives became an official house in Burgesses in 1642 and governed by the Governor's Council appointed by the Crown until Virginia declared independence in 1776.

name: virginia
sentence: The current General Assembly has been the 161st since this year.

name: virginia
sentence: The government now operates under Virginia's seventh Constitution, which was approved by voters in 1971 and is similar to the federal structure in that it provides for three branches: a strong legislature, an executive branch and a unified judicial system.

name: virginia
sentence: The Virginia Legislative Assembly is bicameral with a 100-member House of Delegates and a 40-member Senator, who together draft laws for the Commonwealth.

name: virginia
sentence: Delegates have a two-year term, while senators have a four-year term, with the most recent election taking place in November 2019.

name: virginia
sentence: The Executive Department consists of the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor and the Attorney General, who are elected every four years in separate elections, the next being in November 2021.

name: virginia
sentence: The Governor must be at least 30 years old and the incumbent governors cannot stand for re-election, but the Lieutenant Governor and the Attorney General may, and the governors may and have served non-consecutive terms.

name: virginia
sentence: The Lieutenant Governor is the official leader of the senator, and he is responsible for breaking ties.

name: virginia
sentence: The House elects a Speaker of the House and the Senator elects an Acting Speaker, who presides when the Lieutenant Governor is not present, and both Houses elect a Clerk and majority and minority leaders.

name: virginia
sentence: The Governor also appoints the eleven members of the Cabinet and others who head various departments of state.

name: virginia
sentence: State budgets are proposed in even years by the governor.

name: virginia
sentence: According to data collected up to 2018, the Pew Center on States found that the government of Virginia was above the average surplus, while US News and World Report ranked eighth in fiscal stability.

name: virginia
sentence: The legislature meets annually from the second Wednesday of the year, usually for 60 days in even years and 48 days in odd years because of the state's half-yearly budget, although special sessions may be convened either by the governor or with the agreement of two thirds of the two chambers.

name: virginia
sentence: Special sessions were convened in 2019 on firearms control and in 2020 on police reform and the impact of coronavirus on the state budget.

name: virginia
sentence: The judges and judges who make up the Virginia judicial system, also the oldest in America, are elected by a majority in the House and Senate without the Governor's input, in a way the Virginia legislature is stronger than its executive.

name: virginia
sentence: The system includes a hierarchy between the Supreme Court of Virginia and the Virginia Court of Appeal and circuit courts, general courts of first instance and district courts of first instance and district courts of relations with minors and families.

name: virginia
sentence: The Supreme Court has seven judges serving terms of twelve years, with a mandatory retirement age of 73 years.

name: virginia
sentence: The Supreme Court selects its own Chief Justice from among its seven members, who are informally limited to two four-year terms.

name: virginia
sentence: The Virginia Code is the statutory law and consists of the consolidated legislation of the General Assembly.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia State Police is the largest law enforcement agency in Virginia with 3,022 sworn and civilian members in 2018.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia Capitol Police protect the legislature and is the oldest police force in the United States.

name: virginia
sentence: The Virginia National Guard consists of approximately 7,200 Virginia Army National Guard soldiers, 1,200 Virginia National Air Guard airmen, 300 Virginia Defence Force personnel and 400 civilians.

name: virginia
sentence: Since the resumption of the death penalty in Virginia in 1982, 113 people have been executed, the second largest in the nation, and although no death sentences have been imposed since 2011, two detainees remain on State death row in 2021.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia has the fourth lowest violent crime rate and the 13th lowest real estate crime rate in 2018 according to FBI data.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia terminated her parole in 1995.

sentence: In 2019, the recidivism rate for released offenders who are re-convicted within three years and sentenced to one year or more is 23.1%, the lowest in the country.

name: virginia
sentence: During the 20th century, Virginia moved from a largely rural, politically southern and conservative state to a more urbanized, pluralistic and politically moderate environment.

name: virginia

name: virginia
sentence: The enactment of federal civil rights laws in the mid-1960s, including the Voting Rights Act of 1965, helped to put an end to the laws of Jim Crow of the state that effectively deprived African Americans of their rights.

name: virginia
sentence: The increase in emancipation and demographic changes have further altered the electorate.

name: virginia
sentence: In 1980, 56 per cent of eligible voters were born in the state; in 2019, this figure was 45 per cent, a result of high international immigration and internal migration to the state.

name: virginia
sentence: Regional differences also play an important role in Virginia's policy.

name: virginia
sentence: While growing urban and suburban areas, including much of Northern Virginia, form the basis of the Democratic Party, rural areas in the South and West have moved to support the Republican Party in response to its "Southern Strategy".

name: virginia
sentence: However, rural democratic support persisted in Roanoke, southwestern Virginia, collegial cities such as Charlottesville and Blacksburg, and in the southeastern Black Belt region.

name: virginia
sentence: The state election seasons traditionally begin with the annual Shad Planning event in Wakefield.

name: virginia
sentence: The state elections in Virginia take place in odd years, with the elections to the executive department taking place in the years following the American presidential elections and the Senators' elections in the years preceding the presidential elections, both having a four-year term.

name: virginia
sentence: Elections to the House of Delegates shall be held at the same time as each of these elections, with members holding a two-year term of office.

name: virginia
sentence: National politics often played a role in the results of the state elections, and Virginia elected party governors in front of the US president in ten of the last eleven contests, with only Terry McAuliffe beating the trend.

name: virginia
sentence: The Republicans, however, held a super-majority (68-32) of the seats in the House of Delegates, which they had obtained for the first time in the 2011 state elections.

sentence: Eleven district lines used in these elections, drawn following the 2010 U.S. census, were later found unconstitutional for discrimination against African Americans.

sentence: The state-wide elections of 2017 allowed the Democrats to hold the three highest positions, with outgoing Lieutenant Governor Ralph Northam winning the position of Governor, Justin Fairfax elected Lieutenant Governor, and Mark Herring continuing to serve as Attorney General.

name: virginia
sentence: In the simultaneous elections of the House of Delegates, the Democrats overturned fifteen of the previous majority of the republicans with sixteen seats.

name: virginia
sentence: Control of the House went down to the elections on an equal basis in the 94th district, which was won by the Republicans by the drawing of lots, giving the party a small majority 51–49 in the 2018-2019 legislative sessions.

name: virginia
sentence: Despite a political crisis in February, the Democrats took full control of the General Assembly in the November 2019 elections, the first after several districts were redesigned due to discrimination.

name: virginia
sentence: In 2020, voters adopted a referendum to give control over the drawing of legislative constituencies of Congress and states to a commission composed of eight citizens and four legislators of each of the two main parties, rather than the legislature.

name: virginia
sentence: Although Virginia was considered a "swing state" in the 2008 presidential election, the Democratic candidates won Virginia's 13 electoral votes in that election and the three since, suggesting that the state has moved to be a reliable democrat.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia had already voted for Republican presidential candidates in 13 of the 14 presidential elections from 1952 to 2004, 10 of which were consecutive from 1968 to 2004, but has not voted for a Republican candidate throughout the state since 2009.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia is currently holding its primary presidential election on Tuesday, the same day as thirteen other states, with the most recent election held on March 3, 2020.

name: virginia
sentence: In the U.S. Congress elections since 2006, both parties were successful.

name: virginia
sentence: Republican Senator George Allen lost tight races in 2006, against the new Democrat Jim Webb, and again in 2012, against Webb's replacement, former Governor Tim Kaine.

name: virginia
sentence: In 2008, the Democrats won both seats as Senator of the United States; former Governor Mark Warner was elected to replace outgoing Republican John Warner.

name: virginia
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2010, the Republicans overthrew three seats in the United States House of Representatives, while in the middle of 2018, the Democrats overthrew three Republican seats.

name: virginia
sentence: Of the eleven seats in the House of Representatives, the Democrats currently hold seven seats and the Republicans hold four seats.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia is the most populous American state without a great franchise of professional sports leagues.

name: virginia
sentence: The reasons are the absence of any dominant city or market within the state, the proximity of the teams to Washington, D.C. and North Carolina, and a reluctance to publicly fund stadiums.
