sentence: The new constitution is more inspired by Ohio than Virginia, adopting a model of township government rather than Virginia's "courthouse cliques" than Carlile criticizes, and a compromise required by the Kanawha region (lawyers Charleston Benjamin Smith and Brown) allows counties and municipalities to vote for subsidies for railways or other improvement agencies.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The resulting instrument was ratified (18,162 for and 514 against) on April 11, 1862.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On 13 May 1862 the reorganized state legislature approved the formation of the new state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A request for admission to the Union was made to Congress by Senator Waitman Willey of the restored Virginia government.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, Senator Carlile sought to sabotage the bill by first trying to widen the boundaries of the new state to include the Shenandoah Valley, and then defeating the Willey Amendment at home.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On December 31, 1862, an enabling law was approved by President Abraham Lincoln, who admitted West Virginia, provided that a provision for the progressive abolition of slavery was included in its constitution (as Rev.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Battelle had urged in the Wheeling Intelligence and also wrote to Lincoln).

name: west_virginia
sentence: While many felt that West Virginia's admission as a state was both illegal and unconstitutional, Lincoln expressed his opinion on the admission of West Virginia by concluding that "the organ that consents to the admission of West Virginia is the Virginia Legislative Assembly" and that its admission was therefore both constitutional and timely.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The congress was reconvened on 12 February 1863, and the request for the abolition of the federal enabling law was met.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The revised Constitution was adopted on 26 March 1863 and on 20 April 1863 President Lincoln issued a proclamation in which he admitted the state 60 days later, on 20 June 1863.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Meanwhile, officers for the new state were chosen, while Gov.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Pierpont moved his pro-Union capital Virginia to Alexandria occupied by the Union, where he affirmed and exercised jurisdiction over all other counties of Virginia on federal lines.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The constitutionality of the formation of the new state was then referred to the United States Supreme Court in Virginia v. West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Berkeley and Jefferson counties, located on the Potomac east of the mountains, in 1863, with the consent of the reorganized Virginia government, voted in favour of annexation to Western Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many voters in counties strongly in favour of secessionists were absent from the Confederate Army at the time of the vote and refused to recognize the transfer upon their return.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Virginia General Assembly abrogated the act of secession and, in 1866, brought an action against West Virginia asking the court to declare the counties part of Virginia, which would have declared the admission of West Virginia as an unconstitutional state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Meanwhile, on 10 March 1866, Congress adopted a joint resolution recognizing the transfer.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Supreme Court ruled in favour of West Virginia in 1870.

name: west_virginia
sentence: During the civil war, General Union forces George B. McClellan took possession of most of the territory in the summer of 1861, culminating in the Battle of Rich Mountain, and control of the Union was never again seriously threatened.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 1863, General John D. Imboden, with 5,000 confederates, raided much of the state and burned the Pierpont library, although Senator Willey escaped their control.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Bands of guerrillas burned and looted in some sections, and were not completely removed until after the end of the war.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Eastern Panhandle counties were more affected by the war, as military control of the area changed hands several times.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The region that became Western Virginia has indeed provided about an equal number of soldiers to the federal and Confederate armies, about 22,000 to 25,000 each.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 1865, the Wheeling government found it necessary to remove the voting rights of those returning to their country in order to retain control.

name: west_virginia
sentence: James Ferguson, who proposed the law, said that if it were not enacted, he would lose the election by 500 votes.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The property of the Confederates could also be confiscated and, in 1866, a constitutional amendment depriving all those who had helped and comforted the Confederation was adopted.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The addition of the fourteenth and fifteenth amendments to the United States Constitution prompted a reaction.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The democratic party gained control in 1870, and in 1871 the constitutional amendment of 1866 was repealed.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The first steps towards this change, however, had been taken by the Republicans in 1870.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On August 22, 1872, a new constitution was adopted.

name: west_virginia
sentence: From the reconstruction, and for several decades thereafter, the two states challenged the state's share of the debts of the pre-war government of Virginia, which had been primarily committed to financing the improvement of public infrastructure, such as canals, roads and railways, under the direction of the Virginia Board of Public Works.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Virginians, under the leadership of former Confederate General William Mahone, formed a political coalition based on this: the Readjuster Party.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Although the first constitution of West Virginia provided for the acceptance of part of Virginia's debt, the negotiations opened by Virginia in 1870 were unsuccessful and, in 1871, Virginia financed two thirds of the debt and arbitrarily attributed the rest to West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The issue was finally resolved in 1915 when the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that West Virginia owed Virginia $12,393,929.50.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The last instalment of this amount was paid in 1939.

name: west_virginia
sentence: After the reconstruction, the new 35th State benefited from the development of its mineral resources more than any other economic activity.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Saltpeter caves had been used throughout Appalachia for ammunition production; the border between West Virginia and Virginia included the Saltpeter Trail, a chain of limestone caves containing rich deposits of calcium nitrate that were returned and sold to the government.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The trail extends from Pendleton County to the western terminus of the road in the city of Union, in Monroe County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Nearly half of these caves are on the west side of Virginia, including the organ cave and Haynes Cave.

name: west_virginia
sentence: At the end of the 18th century, Haynes Cave saltpeter miners found large animal bones in the deposits.

name: west_virginia
sentence: They were sent by a local historian and a border soldier, Colonel John Stuart, to Thomas Jefferson.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The bones were called Megalonyx jeffersonii, or big claw, and became known as Jefferson's three-finger sloth.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It was declared an official fossil of the state of West Virginia in 2008.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The official rock of the state of West Virginia is bituminous coal, and the official gemstone of the state is silicified fossil of the Mississippi Lithostrotionella coral.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Limestone has also produced a useful, generally small, quarry industry, and softer, high-calcium seams have been burned to produce industrial lime.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This lime was used for agricultural and construction purposes; for many years, a specific portion of the C & O railway carried limestone to Clifton Forge, Virginia, as an industrial stream.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The extraction of salt had been under way since the 18th century, although it had played largely in the era of the American civil war, when the red salt of Kanawha County was a valuable commodity of the forces of the first Confederation and then of the Union.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the years that followed, more sophisticated extraction methods would restore the role of West Virginia as the leading salt producer.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, in the second half of the 19th century, there was an even larger treasure that was not yet developed: bituminous coal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It would feed much of the industrial revolution in the United States and the steam ships of many of the world's marines.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Residents (indigenous and first European settlers) had long known the underlying coal and could use it for heating and fuel.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For a long time, however, "personal" or artisanal mining was the only practical development.

name: west_virginia
sentence: After the war, with the new railways came a practical method of transporting large quantities of coal to the expansion of American and export markets.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As the anthracite mines in northwestern New Jersey and Pennsylvania began to play during the same period, investors and industrialists focused their interest on Western Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Geologists such as Dr. David T. Ansted studied potential coal fields and invested in land-based and early mining projects.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 1872, the completion of the Chesapeake and Ohio (C&O) railway across the state to the new town of Huntington on the Ohio River opened access to the New River coalfield.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Soon, the C&O was building its huge coal wharf at Newport News, Virginia, on the large harbour of Hampton Roads.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 1881, the new owners of the former Atlantic Railway, Mississippi and Ohio (AM&O), which extended south of Virginia from Norfolk, had clear views of the state of the mountains, where the owners owned vast lands.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Their railway was renamed Norfolk and Western (N&W), and a new railway town was developed in Roanoke to manage the planned expansion.

name: west_virginia
sentence: After his new president Frederick J. Kimball and a small party had travelled on horseback and first-hand saw the rich bituminous seam of coal, which Kimball's wife named Pocahontas, the N&W reoriented its planned expansion westward to reach it.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Soon, the N&W also boarded new coal jetties at Hampton Roads.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 1889, in the southern part of the state, along the Norfolk and western railway lines, the important coal-mining centre of Bluefield, West Virginia, was founded.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The capital of the Pocahontas coalfield, this city would remain the largest city in the southern part of the state for several decades.

name: west_virginia
sentence: She shares a sister town of the same name, Bluefield, Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the northern part of the state and elsewhere, the former Baltimore and Ohio Railroad (B&O) and other lines have also expanded to take advantage of coal opportunities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The B&O has developed coal jetties in Baltimore and several locations on the Great Lakes.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Other major coal rail carriers were the Western Maryland Railway (WM), Southern Railway (SOU) and the Louisville and Nashville Railway (L&N).

name: west_virginia
sentence: One delayer, the Virginian Railway (VGN), was particularly notable.

name: west_virginia
sentence: By 1900, only the most rugged terrain in southwestern Virginia was at any distance from existing railways and mining activities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In this area west of the New River coalfield in Raleigh and Wyoming counties, the Winding Gulf coalfield was later promoted to "Billion Dollar Coalfield".

name: west_virginia
sentence: A protégé of Dr. Ansted was William Nelson Page (1854–1932), a civil engineer and mining director in Fayette County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Former West Virginia Governor William A. MacCorkle described him as a man who knew the land "as a farmer knows a field."

name: west_virginia
sentence: From 1898, Page teamed up with investors from the North and Europe to take advantage of the undeveloped area.

name: west_virginia
sentence: They acquired extensive land in the area, and Page began the Deepwater Railway, a short rail line chartered to stretch between the C&O at its line along the Kanawha River and the N&W at Matoaka, a distance of approximately 80 miles (130 km).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Although the Deepwater plan should have provided a competitive marine transportation contract by either railway, the managers of the two major railways did not appreciate the plan.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In secret collusion, everyone refused to negotiate favorable tariffs with Page, and did not offer to buy their railway, as they had many other short lines.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, if the presidents of the C&O and N&W thought that they could kill the Page project, they had to be wrong.

name: west_virginia
sentence: One of the silent investors was industrial millionaire Henry Huttleston Rogers, senior director of John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Trust, and a former natural resource development and transportation manager.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Master in competitive "war", Henry Rogers did not like to lose in his efforts and also had "deep pockets."

name: west_virginia
sentence: Instead of abandoning, Page (and Rogers) quietly planned and then built their tracks throughout Virginia, using Rogers' private fortune to finance the $40 million cost.

name: west_virginia
sentence: When the Virginian Railway (VGN) was completed in 1909, no fewer than three railways shipped ever increasing volumes of coal to export from Hampton Roads.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia coal was also heavily solicited in Great Lakes harbours.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The NGV and N&W have finally become parts of the modern Norfolk Southern system, and well-developed 21st century NGV tracks continue to provide a favourable gradient for Hampton roads.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As coal mining and related work became important employment activities in the State, working conditions, safety issues and economic concerns arose.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Even in the twenty-first century, mining safety and environmental concerns continue to pose problems for the state whose coal continues to supply power plants in many other states.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Coal is not the only precious mineral found in West Virginia, as the state was the site of the discovery in 1928 of the 34.48 carat Jones diamond (6.896 g).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Located in the Appalachian Mountains, West Virginia covers an area of 62,754.8 km2, with 62,361.0 km2 of land and 393.8 km2 of water, making it the 41st state of the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia borders Pennsylvania and Maryland in the northeast, Virginia in the southeast, Ohio in the northwest and Kentucky in the southwest.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Its longest border is with Virginia at 381 miles (613 km), followed by Ohio at 243 miles (391 km), Maryland at 174 miles (280 km), Pennsylvania at 118 miles (190 km), and Kentucky at 79 miles (127 km).

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is entirely located in the Appalachian region, and the state is almost entirely mountainous, giving the nickname The Mountain State and the motto Montani Semper Liberi ("The mounttains are still free").

name: west_virginia
sentence: Heights and robustness fall near large rivers such as the Ohio River or the Shenandoah River.

name: west_virginia
sentence: About 75% of the state is located in the Cumberland Plateau and the Allegheny Plateau.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Although the terrain is not high, the plateau area is extremely rugged in most areas.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The average altitude of West Virginia is about 1,500 feet (460 m) above sea level, which is the highest of all U.S. states east of Mississippi.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On the eastern line of the state with Virginia, peaks in the Monongahela National Forest region result in an island of cooler climate and ecosystems similar to those in northern New England and eastern Canada.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The highest point in the state is the summit of Spruce Knob, at 1,482 m (1,863 feet), and is covered in dense spruce boreal forest at altitudes greater than 1,200 m (1,000 feet).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Spruce Knob is located in Monongahela National Forest and is part of Spruce Knob-Senatorca Rocks National Recreation Area.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A total of six wild areas are also found in the forest.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Outside the forest to the south, the gorge of the New River is a 300-metre-deep canyon carved by the New River.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The National Parks Service manages a portion of the gorge and river that has been designated as the National Park and gorge reserve of the new river.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Other areas of protection and management include:

name: west_virginia
sentence: Most of Western Virginia is located in the mixed Mesophyte Appalachian ecoregion, while the high elevations along the eastern border and in the panhandle lie in the Appalachian-Blue Ridge forests.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The native vegetation of most of the state was originally a mixed forest of hardwood oak, chestnut, maple, beech and white pine, with American willow and sycamore along the rivers of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many of these areas are rich in biodiversity and picturesque beauty, a fact appreciated by native Virginians, who refer to their home as being almost sky (from the song, "Take Me Home, Country Roads" by John Denver).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Before the song, it was known as "The Cog State" (coal, oil and gas) or "The Mountain State".

name: west_virginia
sentence: The underlying rock strata are sandstone, shale, bituminous coal deposits, and limestone placed in an environment close to the coast from sediments derived from the mountains to the east in a shallow inland sea to the west.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Some beds illustrate coastal marshes, river deltas, shallow waters.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The sea level rose and fell several times during the Mississippi and Pennsylvania eras, giving a variety of rocky strata.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Appalachians are among the oldest on earth, having formed more than three hundred million years ago.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia climate is generally a humid subtropical climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Cfa, except Dfb at higher altitudes) with warm to hot, humid and cold winters, increasing in severity with altitude.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Some regions of the southern highlands also have a temperate mountain climate (Köppen Cfb) where winter temperatures are more moderate and summer temperatures are slightly cooler.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, time is subject in all parts of the state to change.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Hardiness zones range from zone 5b in the Central Appalachian Mountains to zone 7a in the warmest parts of the lowest altitudes.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the Eastern Panhandle and Ohio Valley, temperatures are warm enough to see and cultivate subtropical plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), crepe myrtle, Albizia julibrisin, American sweetgum, and even needle palm and minor sabal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: These plants do not thrive as well in other parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The prickly pear of the east grows well in many parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Average January temperatures range from about 26°F (−4°C) near the Cheat River to 41°F (5°C) along sections of the Kentucky border.

name: west_virginia
sentence: July averages range from 67°F (19°C) along the northern Potomac River to 76°F (24°C) in the western part of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is cooler in the mountains than in the lower sections of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The highest recorded temperature in the state is 112°F (44°C) at Martinsburg on 10 July 1936 and the lowest recorded temperature in the state is -37°F (−38°C) at Lewisburg on 30 December 1917.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Annual precipitation ranges from less than 32 inches (810 mm) in the lower east to more than 56 inches (1,400 mm) in the upper parts of the Allegheny Front.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The eastern valleys are less rainy because the mountain ridges of Allegheny to the west create a partial rain shadow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Just over half of the precipitation occurs from April to September.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Dense fogs are common in many valleys of the Kanawha section, particularly in the Tygart Valley.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is also one of the most cloudy states in the nation, with the cities of Elkins and Beckley ranking 9th and 10th respectively in the United States for the number of cloudy days per year (over 210).

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to a persistent cloudy sky caused by the degradation of moisture by the Alleghenies, West Virginia also experiences some of the most frequent precipitation in the nation, with snowshoes on average nearly 200 days a year with rain or snow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Snow usually lasts only a few days in the lower sections, but may persist for weeks in the upper mountainous regions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On average, 34 inches (860 mm) of snow fall each year in Charleston, although in the winter of 1995-96, more than three times that amount decreased, with several cities in the state setting new snowfall records.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Average snowfall in the Highlands Allegheny can reach up to 180 inches (4,600 mm) per year.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Violent weather is a little less prevalent in West Virginia than in most other eastern states, and it ranks among the least tornado-like states east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the population of West Virginia was 1,792,147 on July 1, 2018, a 3.28 per cent decrease from the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The population centre of West Virginia is located in Braxton County, in the town of Gassaway.

name: west_virginia
sentence: At the 2010 census, the racial composition of the State population was as follows:

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the same year, 1.2% of the population of West Virginia was of Hispanic, Latin or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2019, the population of West Virginia is estimated at 1,792,147, a decrease of 10.025 (0.55%) from the previous year and 47,162 (2.55%) from the previous census.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This includes a natural decrease of 3,296 (108,292 births minus 111,588 deaths) and an increase from the net migration of 14,209 in the State.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is the least populated state in the southeast.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 3,691 people and internal migration resulted in a net increase of 10,518 people.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Only 1.6% of state residents were born abroad, placing West Virginia last among the 50 states in this statistic.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It also has the lowest percentage of residents who speak a language other than English at home (2.6%).

name: west_virginia
sentence: The five largest ancestry groups in West Virginia are: German (18.9%), Irish (15.1%), American (12.9%), English (11.8%) and Italian (4.7%) In the 2000 Census, persons who identified their ethnicity as simply American accounted for 18.7% of the population.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A large number of people of German ancestry are present in the counties of the northeastern part of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: People of English ancestry are present throughout the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many Western Virginians who identify as Irish are actually Scottish-Irish Protestants.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Data from the 2010 census show that 16 per cent of West Virginia residents are 65 years of age or older (exceeding only 17 per cent in Florida).

name: west_virginia
sentence: There were 20,928 births in 2006.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Of these, 19,757 (94.40 per cent of births, 95.19 per cent of the population) were non-Hispanic whites.

name: west_virginia
sentence: There were 22 births of Amerindians (0.11 per cent of births and 0.54 per cent of the population), 177 births of Asians (0.85 per cent of births and 0.68 per cent of the population), 219 births of Hispanics (1.05 per cent of births and 0.88 per cent of the population) and 753 births of Blacks and others (3.60 per cent of births and 3.56 per cent of the population).

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Northern Panhandle and the North Central Region have an affinity for Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition, those in the Eastern Panhandle feel a connection with the suburbs of Washington, D.C. in Maryland and Virginia, and the southwestern Virginians often consider themselves to be Southerners.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Finally, towns and farms along the Mid-Ohio River, which forms most of the western border of the state, have a somewhat Midwest-like appearance and culture.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Note: Births in the table do not add up, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, giving a higher overall number.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Several surveys have been conducted in recent years, in 2008 by the American Religion Identity Survey, in 2010 by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The results of the Pew survey admit a margin of error of 6.5% more or less, while the ARIS survey indicates that the estimates are subject to larger sampling errors in low-population states.

name: west_virginia
sentence: One of the characteristics of religion in the Appalachian communities is the abundance of independent and unaffiliated churches, which "remain unnoticed and not counted in any census of religious life in the United States."

name: west_virginia
sentence: This sometimes leads to the belief that these communities are "unshakable."

name: west_virginia
sentence: The largest denomination in 2010 was the United Methodist Church with 136,000 members in 1,200 congregations.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The second largest Protestant church was the American Baptist Church with 88,000 members and 381 congregations.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Southern Baptist Church had 44,000 members and 232 congregations.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The churches of Christ had 22,000 members and 287 congregations.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Presbyterian Church (USA) had 200 congregations and 20,000 members.

name: west_virginia
sentence: An investigation conducted by the Pew Research Center in 2015 revealed that West Virginia was the seventh most "religious" state in the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia economy would be nominally the 62nd largest global economy behind Iraq and ahead of Croatia according to the 2009 World Bank projections, and the 64th largest behind Iraq and ahead of Libya according to the 2009 International Monetary Fund projections.

name: west_virginia
sentence: According to the November 2010 report of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, the Government planned a nominal GSP of $63.34 billion in 2009 and a real GSP of $55.04 billion.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The real GDP growth of the state in 2009 was the 7th best in the country.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia was one of only ten states in 2009 to have experienced economic growth.

name: west_virginia
sentence: While per capita income fell by 2.6 per cent nationally in 2009, West Virginia increased by 1.8 per cent.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the first half of 2010, exports from West Virginia reached $3 billion, up 39.5 per cent over the same period from the previous year and up from the national average of 15.7 per cent.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Morgantown was ranked by Forbes as the best #10 small town in the nation to run business in 2010.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The city is also home to West Virginia University, the 95th best public university according to US News & World Report 2011.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The proportion of the adult population of West Virginia with a bachelor's degree is lowest in the United States at 17.3%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The net corporate income tax rate is 6.5 per cent, while business costs are 13 per cent below the national average.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis reported that in 2014, the West Virginia economy grew twice as fast as the next state east of Mississippi, ranking third alongside Wyoming and just behind North Dakota and Texas among the fastest growing states in the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Tourism contributed $4.27 billion to the state economy and employed 44,400 people in 2010, making it one of the largest government industries.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many tourists, especially in the eastern mountains, are attracted by the region's remarkable outdoor leisure opportunities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Canaan Valley is popular for winter sports, Senatorca Rocks is one of the leading climbing destinations in the eastern United States, the New River Gorge/Fayetteville area attracts mountaineers as well as water rafters, and Monongahela National Forest is popular with hikers, backpackers, hunters and fishermen.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to these outdoor leisure activities, the State offers a number of historical and cultural attractions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Harpers Ferry National Historic Park is a historic city located at the confluence of the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Harpers Ferry was the site of John Brown's 1859 raid on the Armory and Arsenal of the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Located in the middle of the Appalachian Trail, Harpers Ferry is the base of the Appalachian Trail.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Greenbrier Hotel, built in 1778, has long been considered a leading hotel, frequented by many world leaders and American presidents over the years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is the site of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, which has the Green Bank Telescope.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For the 1963 Centenary of the State, it welcomed two high school graduates from each of the 50 states to the National Youth Science Camp near Bartow, and has continued this tradition ever since.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The main building of the Weston State Hospital is the largest hand-cut sandstone building in the Western Hemisphere, the second largest in the world only at the Kremlin in Moscow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Visits to the building, which is a national historic site and part of the National Civil War Trail, are offered on a seasonal and year-round basis.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia has many popular festivals throughout the year.

name: west_virginia

sentence: Wyoming is a landlocked state in the western United States.

sentence: 10th largest state by region, it is also the least populated and densely populated state of the contiguous United States.

sentence: Almost half of Wyoming's land is owned by the U.S. government, leading Wyoming to rank sixth by region and fifth by proportion of federal government land.

sentence: Federal lands include two national parks – Grand Teton and Yellowstone – two national recreation areas, two national monuments, several national forests, historic sites, fish hatcheries and wildlife refuges.

sentence: The first inhabitants of the area are Arapaho, Crow, Lakota and Shoshone.

name: wyoming
sentence: Southwest Wyoming was claimed by the Spanish Empire and then as Mexican territory until it was ceded to the United States in 1848 at the end of the war between Mexico and America.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired the name of "Wyoming" when a bill was introduced in Congress in 1865 to provide a temporary government for Wyoming territory.

name: wyoming
sentence: The name had been used earlier for the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania, and it is derived from the word Munsee xwé:wam=nk, meaning "to the great river dish".

name: wyoming
sentence: The main drivers of Wyoming's economy are tourism and the extraction of minerals such as coal, oil, natural gas and trone.

sentence: Wyoming has been a politically conservative state since the 1950s, with the Republican candidate holding the state in every presidential election since 1968.

sentence: Teton County, Wyoming's most democratic county, has not voted for a Republican since 2000.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's climate is generally semi-arid and continental (Köppen BSk climate classification), and is drier and more windy than most of the United States with higher extreme temperatures.

name: wyoming
sentence: Much of this is due to the topography of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Summers at Wyoming are warm with high July temperatures between 85 and 95°F (29 and 35°C) in most states.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, with increasing elevation, this mean declines rapidly with locations above 9,000 feet (2,700 m) on average around 70°F (21°C).

name: wyoming
sentence: Summer nights throughout the state are characterized by rapid cooling with even the warmest places on average in the range of 50 to 60 °F (10 to 16 °C) at night.

name: wyoming
sentence: In most of the state, most precipitation tends to fall in late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: Winters are cold, but are variable with periods sometimes extremely cold interspersed between generally mild periods, with Chinook winds providing abnormally warm temperatures in some places.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is a dry state with much of the land receiving less than 10 inches (250 mm) of rain per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: Precipitation depends on altitude with lower areas in the Big Horn Basin of an average of 5 to 8 inches (130 to 200 mm) (which makes the area almost a desert).

name: wyoming
sentence: Lower areas in the North and the Eastern Plains generally have an average of 10 to 12 inches (250 to 300 mm), resulting in a semi-arid climate.

name: wyoming
sentence: Some mountain areas receive a good amount of precipitation, either 20 inches (510 mm) or more, most of which are snow, sometimes 200 inches (510 cm) or more per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: The highest temperature recorded by the State is 114°F (46°C) at Basin on 12 July 1900 and the lowest recorded temperature is -66°F (−54°C) at Riverside on 9 February 1933.

name: wyoming

name: wyoming
sentence: Storm activity in the state was highest in late spring and early summer.

sentence: The southeastern corner of the State is the most vulnerable part of the State to tornado activity.

name: wyoming
sentence: Moving away from this point and westward, the incidence of tornadoes decreases considerably with the western part of the state showing little vulnerability.

sentence: tornadoes, where they occur, tend to be small and brief, unlike some that occur more eastward.

name: wyoming
sentence: As specified in Wyoming Territory Designation Legislation, the boundaries of Wyoming are 41°N and 45°N latitude lines and 104°3'W and 111°3'W (27 and 34 west of the Washington Meridian), a geodetic quadrangle.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is one of the only three states (the others being Colorado and Utah) to have boundaries defined by only "right" lines.
